loans.name: Ya Umu

texts.en:
Ya Umu S. is 42 years old  and is married to a community religious leader who is based in Makeni town. She has seven children:  All are  attending school. Ya Umu sells used clothes and bags in one of the popular markets in the town.  She rents a stall at the market.

Ya Umu has been in this business for more than 5 years. She is very hard-working. She is seeking this loan to purchase more bags.  Ya Umu's goal is to make enough money to keep her children in school.  She is determined that they all will be educated.

loans.use: To purchase used clothing and bags

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther S. is married and has four children. Her husband is a seaman who goes to sea fishing. Esther has received senior high education.

Esther sells different kinds of clothes and bags of water and has been selling them for some time now. She sells them at Kotokoraba market in Abura, Cape Coast. She supports her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills.

Esther’s loan will be used to buy more clothes for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to reinvest in her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Togtohsuren

texts.en:
Togtohsuren T. is the single mother of four children. She currently lives in Omnugobi province with her youngest son who is a student at the local university called Od (Star). The other children have already grown up and live separately with their families.

Togtohsuren started a small retail business since her retirement money was not enough to support her family expenses. She has sold tobacco, candy and chewing gum at the local market since 2003. Later, during summer time, she used to sell ice-cream that was brought from Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia.

Togtohsuren now would like to enter the clothing retail business. Since May 2009, she has started renting a small stall at the local black market where she aims to sell women’s and men’s clothes for all ages. She requests a loan to purchase retail clothes from Ereen, China, a border town from where many cheap Chinese products are imported.

Togtohsuren says that she will work hard to make this business successful and eventually open a clothing store for locals.

loans.use: To purchase clothes to sell

loans.name: Richard

texts.en:
Richard M. is married and has two children. He has been educated to university level. His wife is a trader.

Richard sells men’s clothing and shoes at Kotokraba market in Cape Coast, which he has been doing for the past eleven years. Richard uses his income to pay for his children’s school fees and accommodation.

Richard will use the loan to purchase more shirts and trousers to improve his business. With the new profits from his expanded business, Richard plans to reinvest in his business.

loans.use: To purchase more shirts and trousers for his business

loans.name: Javzandulam

texts.en:
Javzandulam N. is 38 years old and lives with her husband and two teenage daughters in Arhangai province, one of Mongolia's central provinces. Her two daughters are 14 and 17 years old and both go to a local secondary school.

Javzandulam runs a small stall at the local food market where she retails mostly beef. Her husband always helps in her business by visiting local herder families to purchase cattle or cattle carcasses at a cheaper price. Once he purchases the cattle, he slaughters them and cuts them into small pieces for retail at the market.

Since the start of her family business, Javzandulam has gained her customers’ trust for selling good quality beef for good bargains. Her business capital has improved from 200,000 MNT to 1,000,000 MNT (1 USD is approximately 1,440 MNT).

Javzandulam says that one day she hopes to expand her beef retail business by having a small slaughtering house where she would be able to bring more cattle and sell more beef at once. She requests a loan to purchase cattle for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more cattle

loans.name: Hawa Alice

texts.en:
Hawa Alice K. owns a shop at Tikonkoh Road and sells ladies' and gents' wear. She stays with her fiancé, two children,  and two dependents (her mother and niece who help her take care of the shop when she is not around).

Being a very hard-working woman, Hawa has developed her business over a couple of years now and the business has gone well, to the extent that she intends to have a much bigger shop space for her stock.  

In light of this, Hawa is seeking a loan to be able to have a much bigger shop, buy more stock, pay her children's school fees, and attend to other domestic issues.

loans.use: To buy  ladies' and gents' wear

loans.name: Chuluunbaatar

texts.en:
Chuluunbaatar B. is a 28-year-old and currently lives with his 3-year-old daughter. Chuluunbaatar got divorced from his wife in 2008 but lives with his daughter right next to his parents' home.

Chuluunbaatar is a freelance artist. He graduated the School of Arts with a major in ceramics in 2003. Since then, he worked as an assistant artist for a local arts company in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Early this year, he decided to launch his own practice and became a freelance artist. He now makes various artistic items out of bone, various stones, and ceramics. His main customers are foreign tourists who are impressed with local arts. His work is mostly sold through souvenir shops in tourist camps. He says that he enjoys doing ceramics and various traditional artistic work and plans to add more variety of products to his collection.

He requests a loan to purchase necessary frames and raw materials for his arts work.

loans.use: to purchase necessary frames and raw materials

loans.name: Marguerite

texts.fr: H. Marguerite est née le 07 Octobre 1978 à Akpro-Missérété dans le département de l’Ouémé au Bénin. Marguerite vit depuis 15 ans environs au quartier Gankpodo à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à AHOTON Lavenir, Marguerite n’a pas encore d’enfant. Marguerite vit ensemble avec son mari, et lui vient en aide dans les charges de la famille. Marguerite n’a pas été à l’école. Pour faire face à ses besoins, Marguerite vend des ustensiles de cuisine (glacières, bols en séries, seaux en plastique, casseroles en séries, etc.) et aussi des tissus. C’est par le système de distribution que Marguerite mène cette activité. Marguerite s’approvisionne à Lomé au Togo, Etat voisin du Bénin, et aussi à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Marguerite mène cette activité depuis 7 ans et est à son sixième crédit à ALIDé. Marguerite est une bonne cliente de ALIDé, qui rembourse bien ses crédits. C’est dans le but d’augmenter son capital et de renforcer son activité, que Marguerite sollicite ce sixième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Marguerite H. was born on October 7, 1978 in Akpro-Missérété in the department of Ouémé in Benin. She has been living for about 15 years in the neighborhood of Gankpodo in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She is married to Lavenir Ahoton and hasn't yet any children. Marguerite lives with her husband and helps him with the family expenses. She did not attend school.

To make a living, Marguerite sells kitchen utensils (cool boxes, sets of bowls, plastic pails, sets of saucepans, etc.) as well as cloths. She sells her products through the distribution system. She gets her supplies from Lomé in Togo, a country adjoining Benin, as well as from Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. She has been in this business for seven years. This is her sixth loan from Alidé. She is a reliable client who repays her loans on schedule. Marguerite wants to increase her working capital and bolster her activity. Therefore she came to Alidé and applied for her sixth loan.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cool boxes, sets of bowls and cloths

loans.name: Svay

texts.en:
Svay K. is 59 years old and a resident of Pursat Province, where she has owned a plot of land since 1979. She grows rice crops, which she plants twice a year. She is widowed and the mother of five children; three are married and live away from the family home, and two are single and attend school. 

Svay K. is a hard-working woman who never wastes time in order to earn money to ensure that both of her children that are still in school receive a higher education. To help with the hard physical labor involved in her farming work, she is applying for her second loan, which she will use to buy a water buffalo for ploughing the fields.  In the future she proposes to raise water buffalo for babies.

loans.use: to buy a water buffalo

loans.name: Charles

texts.en: Charles S. is married and has five dependents. He has senior high educational background.  Charles sells ready-made ladies' and men's clothes at Kotokraba market in Cape Coast, which he has been doing for the past two years.  His wife is a petty trader.  Charles uses his income to pay his children's school fees and accommodation.  Charles will use the loan to purchase more clothes for resale to improve his business. With the new profits from his expanded business, Charles plans to reinvest into his business.

loans.use: to purchase more clothes for resale

loans.name: Khom

texts.en: Khom R. is 21 years old and resides in an area of Ptasrong Commune in Pursat Province, where she has made a living growing rice or vegetable crops since 2007. She now has two children, both of whom are still young and are living in the family home. Her husband, Manh Bou, 27, sells wood carvings. He purchases wood from the forest to carve himself and sells his wares from village to village in his community, earning around $2 a day. Khom R. will be using her second loan to purchase a plot of farmland in a good location for cultivating, on which she will plant a variety kinds of crops. (R.'s husband is pictured because she was not available.)

loans.use: to purchase a plot of farmland

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy and sell kola nuts

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth E. is married. Elizabeth sells phone cards and accessories at Asikyano near Methodist at Abura, a suburb in Cape Coast, work which she has been doing for some time now. Elizabeth uses her income to help her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills.  Elizabeth will use the loan to purchase more phones and accessories for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Elizabeth plans to save to invest into her business.

loans.use: purchase more phones and accessories for sale

loans.name: Tchaa

texts.en: Mr. M. was born in Kara, but now lives in the Agbalépedo region of Lomé. He has been earning a living selling prepaid cell phone cards since 2008 in Adidogomé.  He is single and has no children. This will be his first loan with WAGES, which he will use to replenish his supply of prepaid cell phone cards.  With this loan, he will continue to benefit from the ever-growing popularity of cell phones in Togo.

loans.use: To purchase prepaid phone cards to sell.

loans.name: Christine

texts.en: Ms. A. sells a variety of fabrics used for clothing. She began her business in 2006 in the Assiyéyé market. She is single and has no children. This will be her first loan with WAGES. She will use the entire loan to replenish her supply of fabrics and maintain a variety of options for her clientele.

loans.use: To purchase fabrics.

loans.name: Komla

texts.en: Mr. K. is a trained carpenter. Currently, he prepares wood for resale. His products can be used for construction or carpentry. He has been running his business from home since 1997. He is divorced and has two children. This will be his second loan with WAGES, which he will use to buy the supplies necessary to make additional wooden poles used for construction.

loans.use: Construction supplies for resale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy and sell cooking salt and onions

loans.name: Adjovi

texts.en: Ms. E. works in various markets throughout Lomé selling a variety of grains. She has been running her business since 2003. She is a single mother with one child. This will be her first loan with WAGES, which she will use to buy ten bags of beans for resale. The profits from her business will help support both her and her child.

loans.use: To purchase beans.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy pagnes for dressmaking

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Sale of Clothes

loans.name: Sakinétou

texts.en: Mrs. A. sells firewood and charcoal. She has been managing her business since 1997. Her husband is a trained civil engineer and they have 2 children. This will be Mrs. A.’s first loan with WAGES, which she will repay in installments for the next 12 months. As her stock continues to sell out, she will use this loan to purchase more charcoal and firewood to help support her family.

loans.use: To buy supplies of firewood and charcoal

loans.name: Hotam

texts.en:
D. Hotam is 30 year old and lives with his wife. He has always worked in agriculture, and since his marriage, he has put his experience to work in the fields so that he and his wife can maintain the well being of their family. Their jobs take up most of their time every day and require plenty of hard work, but they enjoy it. They are especially proud of their produce, which they care for by purchasing manure and fertilizer which help them to grow their crops successfully. The cost of these necessary items, however, is very high. Hotam must care for his children every day and this is his main motivation to work hard. He would like to make an investment in his crop, so that the sale of his produce which will be profitable and provide a bright future for his children.   


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy the seeds and mineral fertilizer for sowing potato and onions

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en: Samuel O. sells electrical appliances at Pedu, near Abura in cape coast. He is married. Samuel has been selling electrical appliances for quite some time now. He is responsible for paying school fess and utility bills. His loan will be used to buy more electrical appliances for sale. He hopes to use the new profits from his business to save and to invest into his business.

loans.use: His loan will be used to buy more electrical appliances for sale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buying and selling soap

loans.name: Abdumavlon

texts.en:
I. Abdumavlon is 55 years old. He is married and has eight children. His wife manages the household, while Abdumavlon's transport business is the main source of income for his large family. Abdumavlon has been providing transport services for the last 27 years. Each day he uses his lorry to transport construction materials for his clients. Abdumavlon's dream is for all of his children to be well-educated. He is working hard to realize it. As a result, his business generates a significant income, allowing him to support his large family. In order to provide better service to his clients and, thus, to earn more, Abdumavlon needs to make major repairs to his lorry. He believes that this will make his business more profitable. With this purpose, he is requesting $3,000. The well-being of this family is in your hands.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts for a lorry.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buying and selling pagne cloth

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase and sale of "pagnes"

loans.name: Shamsiddin

texts.en:
Shamsiddin is 25 years of age. He lives with his wife and two children. Shamsiddin is a sheep breeder and has been doing this for five years. Thanks to this activity, he can cover the expenses of his family. For this reason, he goes out every morning to graze his animals so they can eat. He enjoys caring for his animals, because thanks to this business he can take a meal to his children. Shamsiddin’s family is his greatest love and they are the biggest motivators in his life. The loan he is requesting will be invested in the purchase of young sheep, which will help to improve his business and help him become the best breeder in his area. With your help, this will be possible.

loans.use: To purchase sheep

loans.name: Shohsarvar

texts.en:
Shohsarvar lives in Istaravshan, Tajikistan. He's married and has two children. Due to the difficulty in finding employment, five years ago Shohsarvar started his own business selling clothes and shoes. He works at markets and is helped by his wife. Together they have been able to move the business forward. It is their only source of income. The quality of their products and the good service they offer has allowed them to quickly increase their clientele. To keep the business growing, Shohsarvar is requesting a loan of $1500 USD, which he will use to purchase merchandise to offer a wider variety to his clients. Shohsarvar and his wife are very grateful for your confidence and support.

loans.use: To purchase more goods to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase and sale of "pagnes"

loans.name: Biova

texts.en: Mr. A. is a trained electrician. Currently he sells cell phones and accessories. He has been running this business since 2007.  He is single and has no children. This will be Mr. A.’s second loan with WAGES. He will use the loan to expand his supply of cell phones and accessories. Specifically, he plans to purchase several Nokia cell phones, Blue Tooth supplies, cell phone batteries, and chargers. With this loan, Mr. A. will continue to benefit from this increasingly popular market.

loans.use: To purchase cell phones and accessories

loans.name: Oisha

texts.en:
K. Oisha is 50 years old and is an admirable mother. Together with her husband (pictured), she has shown a great, diligent spirit and enthusiasm for agricultural work. This activity has let them educate their children. Oisha continues to strive towards providing well-being and education for her children and towards being able to cover the expenses that her delicate health requires every day. As a result of this, her work has been very limited, and her profits have decreased notably. Since Oisha now wishes to increase the quality of her products by purchasing fertilizers. Her goal is to obtain a larger income to keep providing her children with education and improve the living conditions. She is requesting a loan of 4,000 Somoni, which she will use to make her dreams a reality.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Koffi

texts.fr: A. koffi est un jeune homme célibataire. Pour  pouvoir satisfaire ses besoins, il s’est lancé en 2004 dans la vente de détail des matériaux de construction. Son dynamisme a fait que plus tard il a ouvert sa propre boutique. Ce commerce lui réussit bien. Mais il  a reçu en ce moment une commande qu’il ne peut satisfaire avec son stock actuel. Il sollicite alors de WAGES son premier crédit pour acheter un fil , une balance, 1 targette forgeron, 3 canaux et des serrures.
texts.en:
Koffi A. is a young single man. In order to satisfy his needs, he began retailing building materials in 1994. His dynamism led him later on to open his own shop. This business has been successful. But he has an order at present that he cannot fulfil with his current stock. He is therefore asking for his first loan from WAGES in order to buy a cable, some scales, a blacksmith's bolt, three conduits and some locks.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cable, scales, blacksmith's bolt, conduits and locks

loans.name: Christine Nduku

texts.en: Christine is married and has two children.  She runs the Dema Chemist and Cosmetics Shop, where she sells cosmetics, pain killers and antibiotics to walk-ins and frequent customers.  Her business has been located at Ninth Street in Eastleigh town for the last two years.  Her business challenges are competition from similar businesses and price inflation of products.  Christine will use her loan of KES 20,000 to increase her stock of cosmetics.

loans.use: to buy cosmetics

loans.name: Matousiba

texts.fr: En 2005 cette dame a commencé le commerce de céréales, étant mariée et mère de 04 enfants, le revenu qu’elle perçoit de son activité lui permet d’apporter sa contribution financière à son foyer. Elle s’approvisionne à Lomé et parfois à l’intérieur du pays, elle fait face en ce moment à une baisse de stock de maïs, pour pouvoir se réapprovisionner elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour acheter 15 sacs de maïs.
texts.en:
Matousiba Y. started her cereal business in 2005. She is married and is the mother of 4 children. The profits that she earns from her business allows her to contribute to her family's financial needs. She buys her supplies in Lome and occasionally in the interior of the country. She is now experiencing a low level with her supplies of corn. To restock her inventory she is requesting a loan from WAGES to buy 15 sacks of corn.

Translated from French by David Gibbons, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sacks of corn

loans.name: Godffrey Irungu

texts.en: Godffrey Irungu M. is married and has four children.  He describes himself as hardworking and a leader. He has been selling fruits and vegetables to regular customers and walk-ins for the last fifteen years.  He has one employee.  His business challenges are lack of proper storage and insecurity in the area.  Godffrey will use his loan of KES 50,000 to buy more fruits and vegetables.  In the future, he wants to be a wholesaler.

loans.use: to buy more fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Sohibnazar

texts.en:
R. Sohibnazar is 41 years old. He has a successful business selling flour at the local market in Kabodien region. Sohibnazar sells an assortment of good quality flours. In the picture you can see Sohibnazar with his guarantor of the loan. Because he buys the flour at wholesale, the price is cheaper than the price of his competitors. Thus, he has many customers who even make a purchase of his flour straight from his house. Today he has a great demand for his goods and that is why he wants to take an individual loan. Sohibnazar has requested a loan of 13,000 Somoni to add to his working capital and allow him to purchase more inventory. He is ready to work even harder, make sacrifices and push every once in a while to achieve his goal and become a successful entrepreneur. We believe his perseverance and clear vision will become key success factors in his small business. 


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. loans.use: To purchase more flour to sell

loans.name: Paul Loka

texts.en: Paul is married and has children ranging from four to nine years old.  He describes himself as hardworking, dedicated and humble.  For the last six years Paul has been running a green grocer, and has one employee.  His business challenges are lack of proper storage and unreliable transportation.  He will use his loan of KES 50,000 to increase his stock so that he can operate another grocery store.  In the future, he wants to be a wholesaler.

loans.use: to increase his stock so he can operate another grocery store

loans.name: Katusenvule Group, Lugazi

texts.en:
S. Isma is the leader of his group in Lugazi. He is a married man with five children, all of whom are in primary school. In total, he takes care of six dependants. 

For the past six years, Isma has been in the business of selling produce, mostly beans and maize from Buloba. He admits that his main challenge is not having enough capital, although he is trying to fight this with the help of loans. He is able to make 35,000 Ugandan shillings (UGX) in weekly profits and, once he enlarges his business, he hopes to increase this amount.

Isma needs a loan to be able to buy more beans and maize for resale, since such transactions help his business expand. He has worked hard to win his customers’ trust. His major goal is to ensure that he is able to pay his children’s school fees to the highest level of education. He would also like to build houses for them as they grow up.

loans.use: Buying more beans and maize for resale.

loans.name: Ulmas

texts.en:
Ulmas R. is 50 years old. She is a self-sacrificing mother with two children. Ulmas began dedicating herself to agricultural labor, which failed due to the low income of her husband. Thanks to good fortune she can smile in the face of this event and has hopes of being able to economically recuperate. 

Ulmas is requesting 4,000 Tajikistan Somoni (TJS) to invest in purchasing cattle that will allow her to increase her earnings. This way Ulmas will be able to finish remodeling her home in order to give her family better security and not be easy prey for the thieves that have had the opportunity of disturbing her home. Collaborate with this wife and mother so that she can achieve her goals.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan
Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history and diverse culture, which is a mix of the Islamic faith, Soviet influence, and Central Asian traditions. It served as a key post along the Silk Road and marked the end of Alexander the Great's extensive rule. It was the birthplace of the great Persian poet Rudaki and famous Islamic philosopher Ibn Sina. And it is home to epic mountain passes, communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing cattle in order to expand the business and to improve the living conditions of the family.

loans.name: Abduvahob

texts.en:
Abduvahob Y. is 47 years old and lives with his wife and two children. 

Abduvahob has been breeding cattle for more than 12 years. He is trying to improve the breed in order to increase his prices. He invests time and money in the feed and medicines that the animals require. He enjoys this work. Above all, he enjoys getting milk from his cows, which he sells in local markets. 

Abduvahob keeps going thanks to the help and enthusiasm of his children and his wife, who help him care for the animals. Now Abduvahob needs a loan of 3,500 Tajikistan Somoni (TJS) to purchase more cattle in order to expand his business. With your help this will be possible.

loans.use: To purchase cattle to expand his business.

loans.name: Suubi Lyamukama Group 3, Lugazi

texts.en: N. Agnes is a single mother of seven children and divorced from her husband. Her four children are still in school and she also cares for orphans. She is a determined lady with two businesses to manage. She has a poultry farm as well as being a farmer in Kitigoma. Her major challenge is the expensive feed for her chicken. She works hard to be able to make 150,000 a week profits from her transactions. Her advantages are her good customer care skills and the help from loans for business investments. She hopes to become the leading poultry farmer so that she will be able to build rental houses. Agnes needs a loan to be able to buy more chicken feeds for her poultry farm plus pesticides for her farming business.

loans.use: Buying chicken feed and pesticides for her farming business.

loans.name: Djatougbé

texts.en: Mrs. W. has been managing her general grocery store since 1992. She is married and has 3 children. This will be her first loan with WAGES, which she will use to buy a variety of grocery products. Specifically, she will purchase additional stock in rice, oil, couscous, tomatoes, milk, soap, spaghetti, and other diverse products. This loan will help keep her clients happy and allow her to help support her family.

loans.use: A variety of grocery supplies

loans.name: Salome Mbatha

texts.en: Salome is married and has three children.  She describes herself as hardworking, active and jovial.  For the last five years, Salome has been making and selling dresses, skirts and trousers to regular customers and walk-ins.  She has three employees and her business is located at Gikomba market in Nairobi.  This is the largest and busiest open air market in Kenya. Her biggest business challenge is a lack of loyal and reliable customers.  She will use her loan of KES 50,000 to buy more materials for making dresses.

loans.use: to buy material for making dresses

loans.name: Mirzokul

texts.en:
Mirzokul is 37 years old and married with four children. He is a very optimistic man in spite of the circumstances he has endured. Mirzokul raises cattle, work which helps him meet his family’s expenses. He has a great appreciation for animals, and his work helps him considerably in supporting his children and providing daily bread for his home. Mirzokul wishes to increase his number of cattle and therefore increase his earnings. He hopes that you can help him by funding his loan application. You could become an important part of his family's life. Mirzokul deeply appreciates the trust and support you are giving him.

More about Tajikistan
Tajikistan, a key post on the Silk Road, is perhaps best known for its rich history. It was the location for the end of Alexander the Great's rule, and is known for its great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets such as Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country, with its epic mountain passes, is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language and a civilization that dates back to the fourth millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mix of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.
However, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the USSR, damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93 per cent of the country is mountainous and only 7 per cent of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands of people to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase cattle to expand his business

loans.name: Catherine Sila

texts.en: Catherine Sila E. is married and her husband works as a chef.  They have three daughters: twin twelve-year-olds and an eighteen-year-old.  She describes herself as hardworking and optimistic.  For the last seven years Catherine has been selling baby wear, dresses and tops to walk-ins and frequent customers.  She has one employee.  Her business challenges are strong competition and transportation problems during the rainy season.  She will use her loan of KES 20,000 to buy more clothes to sell.  Her goal in life is to own a big boutique.

loans.use: to buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Nile Group 1, Lugazi

texts.en:
N. Maine is the leader of her lending group in Jinja. She is a widow with seven children, all still in school, and she also takes care of three more dependants. For the last 12 years, Maine has had a business selling fresh bananas from Njeru trading center. Her major challenge is transporting goods to her stall. She is able to make 100,000 UGX as profits a week and attributes this to acquired trust from her customers and her good customer care skills.
Maine hopes to set up her own banana plantation in order to reap from the sale of her own produce. She also wants to build a house for her children and be able to pay their school fees. Maine is requesting a loan to buy more bananas for resale.

loans.use: To buy more bananas for resale

loans.name: Grace Nyambura

texts.en:
Grace has been running the Pegra Auto Spares hardware and selling spare parts to mechanics over the last few years. She has one employee. Her business challenge is lack of funds and strong competition. She is using this loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings to buy more spare parts. In the future, she wants to be a supplier of containers of auto spare parts.

Grace is married and has seven children. She describes herself as a person of good morals and dedicated to her work.

loans.use: To add stock of spare parts

loans.name: Milkah

texts.en: For the last six years, Milkah has been running the Sharp Minds Junior Academy in a conducive place for learning. She has ten employees. Her business challenges are high rent and inadequate space for sports. She is using this loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings to add more tables and chairs. In the future, she wants to run a bigger school. Milkah is married and has three children. She describes herself as hardworking and ambitious.

loans.use: To buy more chairs and tables for a school

loans.name: Jennifer Wanjiru

texts.en: Jennifer Wanjiru runs a hardware and sells goods such as paint, spare parts and electrical wires among other things to regular customers and walk-ins. She has been in business for the last two years. Her business challenges are low demand from customers and high electricity bills. She will be using this loan of 50,000 Kenyan shillings to buy more engine oil, spare parts and nails. In the future, she wants to become the main supplier in the area. Jennifer is married and has two children. She describes herself as hardworking and honest.

loans.use: To buy engine oil, spare parts and nails

loans.name: Esteria Ngithi

texts.en: Esteria Ngithi N. runs Bessy hardware, where she sells goods like paints, engine oils, plumbing materials, nails and spare parts to new and frequent customers.  Her business challenge is low demand from customers, hence making small sales.  She plans to use the proceeds of a KES70,000 loan to restock the hardware in her store.  Her lifetime goal is to open another branch.  Esteria is married and has three children ranging from 9 to 16 years old.  She describes herself as hardworking and honest.

loans.use: To buy engine oils, nails, spanners and paints.

loans.name: Johna Mutugi

texts.en: Johna sells fruits and has one employee.  His business challenges are lack of proper storage and insecurity.  He plans to use the proceeds of a 50,000KES loan to buy more fruits.  In the future, he wants to have a permanent grocery store.  Johna is married and has two children, 7 and 9 years old.  He describes himself as hardworking and social.

loans.use: To restock fruits.

loans.name: God Cares Group, Lugazi

texts.en:
O. Edith is the leader of her group in Lugazi. She is married with 12 children, some of whom have completed university while others are in secondary and primary education. She also takes care of six dependants.
Edith is a farmer with plantations. For the last five years, she has also sold milk from her own cows in Naminya. She makes 40,000 UGX weekly profits but has limited capital. Edith would like to own more cows in order to expand her business She would also like to build more rental houses to be able to educate her children well. Edith is requesting a loan to buy another cow, and is happy that the loans have increased her capital.

loans.use: To buy another cow

loans.name: Djekabaara Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Djekabaara est composé de quatre femmes (3 veuves et 1 mariée) ayant en moyenne 44 ans, 7 enfants  et vivant dans des familles polygames dans le quartier Pelengana Extension de la ville de Ségou  4ème Région administrative de la république du Mali. 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et de leurs activités commerciales. Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce d’articles divers et la fabrication du pain local appelé  ‘Takoula.’’ 
Après avoir correctement remboursés tous les six prêts précédents, elles sont à leur 7ème  prêt  solidaire.
 Ce nouveau prêt  sera utilisé pour acheter,  4 paires de rideaux, 3 paires de draps en coton,10 pièces de pagnes fancy, 4 sacs de mil, des condiments alimentaires (notamment : 1 panier de tomate fraîche, ½ panier de gros piment frais,1/2 panier de poivron,1 sac de poudre de feuilles de baobab,1 paquet de cubes maggi poulet),  4 sacs de mil, 5kg de farine de blé, 5kg de sucre, 4 paquets de levure, 6kg de gingembre, 2kg de sel de cuisine et 250g de « fèfè » 
Elles s’approvisionnent en draps, rideaux, en pagnes fancy,  au marché château de Ségou, en condiments alimentaires à la foire hebdomadaire de Ségou, en mil à Semembougou  et les ingrédients nécessaires à la préparation du ‘’Takoula’’  dans les boutiques de la place. 
Le ‘’ Takoula’’ s’obtient en faisant un mélange de farine de mil (10kg) et la farine de blé (2kg), on y ajoute du sucre, de la levure, du sel, du gingembre et du « fèfè », malaxer ce mélange avec de l’eau jusqu’à obtenir une pâte, laisser quelques temps puis en faire des boules de cinq et les faire cuir à la vapeur dans une marmite percée et qui sont vendues essentiellement les vendredis. 
Les articles sont vendus au grand marché de Ségou, au marché château,  à domicile et en ambulant dans le quartier. La vente se fait en détail, au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’homme et de femmes 
Elles espèrent réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 15.500FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement du prêt de Soro Yiriwaso et à la prise en charge des dépenses familiales.
texts.en:
The group Djekabaara is composed of four women (3 widows and 1 married), who are on average 44 years old, with an average of 7 children each and who live in polygamous families in the neighborhood of Pelengana Extension in the town of Ségou, in the 4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali. They know each other through the neighborhood and through their businesses. This group of women sells a variety of articles and bakes a local type of bread known as "Takoula". Having correctly repaid their previous 6 loans, they are requesting their 7th loan. They will use this loan to purchase 4 sets of curtains, 3 sets of cotton sheets, 10 sets of fancy "pagnes" (brightly colored cotton cloth), 4 sacks of millet, various condiments (notably: 1 crate of fresh tomatoes, 1/2 a crate of large fresh hot peppers, 1/2 a crate of peppers, 1 sack of powdered baobab tree leaves, 1 packet of maggi chicken stock cubes), 4 sacks of millet, 5 kilograms of wheat flour, 5 kilos of sugar, 4 packets of yeast, 6 kilos of ginger, 2 kilos of cooking salt and 250 grams of "fèfè" (a spice which can be used as a substitute for black pepper). They will supply themselves with curtains, fabric and fancy "pagnes" from the market house of Ségou, for condiments they supply themselves from the weekly food market in Ségou, millet from Semembougou and the necessary ingredients for the preparation of ‘’Takoula’’ from the local stores. The ‘’ Takoula’’ is made using a mixture of millet flour (10kg) and wheat flour (2kg), then they add some sugar, yeast, salt, ginger and "fèfè". They mix these ingredients with water until it is a dough; they leave it for a whole and then separate it into five balls and steam it in a pot. They mostly sell the product on Fridays. They sell their items in the large market of Ségou, within the market house, from their homes and walking throughout the neighborhood. They sell their goods at retail for cash and credit to a clientele composed of men and women. They hope to realize a monthly income of 15,500 FCFA each, which they will use to repay Soro Yiriwaso for their loans and take care of family expenses.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase a variety of products

loans.name: Tièssiri Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Tièssiri est composé de quatre femmes (une veuve et 3 mariées) ayant en moyenne 47 ans, 5 enfants et vivant majoritairement dans des familles monogames dans  le quartier Pelengana Extension de la ville de Ségou 4ème Région administrative de la république du Mali. 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de leurs activités commerciales et d’appartenance à une même Association traditionnelle des femmes du dit quartier.
Dans le souci de pérenniser leurs activités commerciales, elles ont décidé d’intégrer le   programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle elles sont à leur 7ème  prêt de groupe. Tous les six prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Ce nouveau prêt sera utilisé pour acheter, 6 sacs de mil, 150 kg de haricot, 50 kg de riz, 20 pièces de pagnes fancy, 2 pièces de 30 mètres de bazin blanc, 15 morceaux de soude caustique, une dizaine de sachet de couleurs pour la teinture.  
Elles s’approvisionnent  en grain (mil, haricot, riz)  au marché château de Ségou et à Banankoro,  en pagnes fancy et  bazin au grand marché de Ségou. Quant aux autres articles ils sont achetés auprès de grossistes de la place. Le bazin est teint avant de le mettre sur le marché. 
La vente des articles de groupe se fait, la plupart du temps au marché château et à domicile  au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’homme et de femmes. 
Elles  envisagent réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 30.750FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement du prêt de Soro Yiriwaso,  à la prise en charge des dépenses familiales, à la participation aux évènements sociaux (baptêmes, mariages, circoncisions et funérailles) et à  la constitution d’épargne.  
Leurs ambitions sont avoir, une concession à usage d’habitation, du matériel de travail de menuiserie pour leurs enfants et pour d’autres avoir du matériel agricole.
texts.en:
The group Tièssiri is composed of four women (one widowed and three married) who average 47 years of age and five children each living in monogamous families in the Pelengana Extension district of Ségou City (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  The women know one another through ties of community, commercial work, and membership in the same traditional women's association of the aforementioned district.  Concerned about ensuring that their businesses will continue, they decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are now on their seventh group loan.  The preceding six loans have all been properly repaid. This new loan will be used to buy six sacks of millet, 150 kg of beans, 50 kg of rice, twenty bolts of Fancy pagnes (colorful West African cloth), two 30-meter bolts of white damask, fifteen pieces of caustic soda, and about ten pouches of dyes.  Supplies of grains (millet, beans, rice) are gotten at the Château market of Ségou and in Banankoro; and supplies of Fancy pagnes and of damask are gotten from the big market of Ségou.  As for the other items, these are purchased from wholesale merchants locally.  The damask is dyed before being put on the market.  Sales of group items are made most of the time at the Château market and at home.  Cash or credit is accepted from customers composed of men and women.  The group members envision realizing an average monthly profit of 30,750 francs CFA that will be used to repay the Soro Yiriwaso loan, to cover family expenses, to assist with societal events (baptisms, marriages, circumcisions, and funerals), and to accumulate savings. Their ambition is to obtain a concession as a place to live, woodworking supplies and equipment for the children, and farming supplies for some others.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying various goods

loans.name: Agua Bella Group

texts.es: El banco comunal "Agua Bella " esta representado por la señora Olga y conformado por 12 miembros socias muy trabajadores como lo han demostrado en sus dos ciclos anteriores, muchas de ellas son vecinas del mismo barrio o compañeras de trabajo, por lo que se conocen y confían en cada miembro del grupo. Dentro de las actividades que realizan las socias cuentan con puestos de venta en el mercado de diferentes productos como abarrotes, desayunos, comida, cosméticos varios y algunas socias se dedican a la fabricación pan, muebles de madera y a la elaboración de prendas de vestir. En cuanto al entorno competitivo podemos mencionar que sus competidores tienen la misma gama de productos y que su competencia es alta, pero las socias saben que un buen trato a los clientes hace la diferencia para vender mas y obtener un mejor ingreso que la competencia. El destino del financiamiento para la adquisición de materia prima como madera, tela, harina, azúcar y para la adquisición de herramientas de trabajo como una cocina para las vendedoras de comida, desayunos y para el resto adquisición de mercadería al por mayor para mejorar sus ingresos y poder darles a sus familias una mejor calidad de vida. En cuanto a la experiencia crediticia las socias ya van cursando su tercer ciclo agradeciendo la confianza y el apoyo económico que le brinda Agrocapital ya que gracias  a ello pueden seguir creciendo para darles un mejor futuro a sus hijos.
texts.en:
The community bank "Agua Bella" is represented by Olga and composed of 12 hard working partner members, as has been demonstrated in previous loan cycles. Many of the members are neighbors from the same neighborhood or coworkers, so every member knows and trusts one another. During their business activities, the partners use market stalls to sell products such as groceries, breakfasts, food, and various cosmetics; some partners devote themselves to the production of bread, wood furniture, and clothing items. In regards to the high level of competition with other businesses who sell the same range of products, the partners know that excellent customer service is makes a huge difference in selling more and obtaining higher sales than their competitors. The loan will be used for the acquisition of raw materials such as wood, cloth, flour, and sugar as well as the acquisition of work tools like a stove for the food sellers. The rest of the loan money will be used for the purchase of merchandise which will allow the businesses to improve their income and enable the partners to give their families a higher quality of life. In terms of their credit history, their partners are already in their third cycle and appreciate the confidence and the economic support that Agrocapital offers. Thanks to them, the partners are able to continue growing and give their children a better future.

Translated from Spanish by Colleen Godfrey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating Capital

loans.name: Centro De Salud Group

texts.es: El grupo “Centro D. Salud” esta representado por la señora Ines y conformado por 17 miembros los cuales se caracterizan por ser personas que buscan progresar en las distintas actividades que realizan para poder cumplir con sus familias y con sus obligaciones. Entre las actividades que realizan las socias se encuentra la venta D. pan, D. comida, cosméticos, refrescos, empanadas y el resto D. las socias se dedican a al transporte público y como empleadas en empresas varias. En cuanto al entorno competitivo es alto, ya que todos tienen que trabajar duro para poder sacar adelante sus negocios. El crédito lo destinaran a la mejora D. sus negocios y a ala adquisición D. mercadería, insumos y herramientas para un mejor trabajo y generar mejores ingresos para poder darles a sus familias una mejor calidad D. vida.  Algunas D. las socias ya tienen experiencia trabajando con grupos solidarios gracias a financiamientos con instituciones similares a la Fundación Agrocapital a quien le dan las gracias por la confianza depositada y el apoyo económico que necesitaban para salir adelante.
texts.en:
The Centro D. Salud group is represented by Ines. It is comprised of 17 members who are characterized as being people who look to progress in the different activities they do in order to be able to meet their families’ needs and their obligations. Among the activities that they do you will find selling bread, food, cosmetics, soft drinks, and empanadas. The rest of the members work in public transportation or as employees in various businesses. As far as competition goes, it is high. All of them have to work hard to be able to get ahead in their businesses. The loan is to improve their businesses and to acquire merchandise, supplies, and tools to do better work and generate better income. They do this to give their families a better quality of life. Some of the members already have experience working with communal banks thanks to loans with institutions similar to the Agrocapital Foundation. They are grateful to Agrocapital for having confidence in them and for the economic support they needed to get ahead.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital

loans.name: Kajekaire Group, Jinja

texts.en:
Lydia Y., the leader of her group in Jinja, is a hard-working lady who has operated a salon business for the past two years. She tends primarily to ladies’ hair although she hopes to open up a men’s section. Because her salon is still small, she is able to make only 30,000/= as weekly profits, but she would like this to increase through additional investment.

Lydia is requesting a loan to buy more hair oils, chemicals, braids, weaves and combs so that her customers will have a greater variety to choose from. Currently employing one person who helps her to attend to her customers’ needs, she plans to hire more staff to offer a greater variety of hair styles and also hopes to develop bridal services.

loans.use: Buying more hair oils, chemicals, braids and weaves for salon expansion.

loans.name: Las Tequileras Group

texts.es: El grupo “Las Tequileras” están representadas por la señora Delmira y conformada por 13 miembros que van cursando juntas un nuevo ciclo demostrando responsabilidad y ganas de salir adelante siempre. Cada una de las socias tiene diferentes actividades económicas pero una mayoría se dedica a la venta de ropa para todas las edades y comida variada en el mercado, el resto de las socias una minoría se dedican a la venta y elaboración de pan y la presidenta realiza servicios como manicurista. Dentro del ámbito competitivo se puede decir que existe en gran cantidad, incluso dentro del mismo grupo pero depende mucho de la clase de ropa que se venda su calidad y su forma de vender, entre las vendedoras de comida siempre cumplen su nivel optimo de ventas por lo que no tienen mayores percances. El destino del financiamiento es para la adquisición de mercadería de temporada, tambien lo destinaran para la compra de insumos, materia prima y herramientas para mejorar sus ventas y generar un mayor ingreso que les permita brindarles a sus familias una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Delmira represents the “Las Tequileras” group, which is comprised of 13 members. Together they are in a new cycle; they demonstrate responsibility and the desire to get ahead. Each one of the members has a different economic activity. Most of them sell clothes for all ages and various foods in the market. The rest of the members, a minority, make bread. The president is a manicurist. There is a great deal of competition, even within the group. It depends a lot on the type of clothes being sold, their quality, and the way they sell. The food sellers always have an optimal level of sales so they do not have big problems. The loan is to get seasonal merchandise. They will also get supplies, raw material, and tools to improve their sales and generate greater income. This will allow them to give their families a better quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy and sell clothing and school supplies

loans.name: Kyagalanyi Masajja Group, Central

texts.en:
M. Margaret is 30 years old and married with 3 children ages 11, 3 and 9 months.  She also takes care of 3 other dependents. Margaret has had a drug shop in Masajja A zone for 7 years and she is able to make 100,000/= (Ugandan Shillings) as profit almost every week due to her stock and good customer care.

Margaret struggles for this profit margin to increase since she works towards having a first class drug shop and becoming a rich family. She is such a hard working lady and needs a loan to be able to buy more drugs for her shop.

loans.use: Buying more drugs for her shop.

loans.name: Bayi Houévi Marie

texts.fr: H. Bayi Houévi Marie  est née le 17 Octobre 1965 à Agoué au Bénin. Marie vit depuis 8 ans à Bazoukpa, non loin de Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à HOUENOU Léopold, un commerçant, Marie est mère de quatre enfants, tous scolarisés. Marie vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari à Bazounkpa. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Marie a fréquenté jusqu’au cours secondaire. Depuis environs 5 ans, Marie vend des tissus et des vêtements, par le système de distribution. C’est à Lomé au Togo, Etat voisin du Bénin, que Marie s’approvisionne. C’est la première fois que Marie sollicite un crédit auprès de ALIDé. Ce crédit lui servira à élever le niveau de son activité pour mieux satisfaire sa clientèle. Marie envisage plus tard ouvrir une boutique pour y vendre ses produits.
texts.en:
Bayi Houevi Marie H. was born on October 17, 1965, at Agoue, in Benin. Marie lived for 8 years in Bazoukpa, not far from Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Married to Leopold Houenou a businessman, Marie is the mother of for school aged children. Marie lives together with her children and husband in Bazounkpa. Together, the couple support the needs of the family. Marie has attended secondary school. For the last five years Marie has sold fabrics and clothing using a door to door distribution sales system. Marie buys her supplies from Lome in Togo, a country neighboring Benin. This is the first loan Marie has requested from ALIDe. This loan will be used to increase the size of her business to better meet the needs of her clientele. In the future, Marie hopes to open a kiosk to sell her products.

Translated from French by David Gibbons, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 20 pieces of fabric

loans.name: Cossiba Victorine

texts.fr: G. Cossiba Victorine est née le 02 Mai 1965 à Bopa au Bénin. Victorine est mariée à AMOUSSOU Félix un entrepreneur. Le couple a deux enfants, qui sont tous scolarisés. Victorine vit avec ses enfants à Cococodji non loin de Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Victorine est dans ce quartier depuis environs 5 ans. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Victorine n’a pas été à l’école, mais a appris la coiffure. Victorine exerce ce métier depuis 4 ans. Victorine vend aussi dans son atelier, des produits cosmétiques, des bijoux, des mèches et aussi des tissus. C’est à Lomé au Togo, Etat voisin du Bénin, et aussi à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Victorine s’approvisionne. Dans le but de renforcer son activité afin de mieux satisfaire la demande des clients, Victorine sollicite un premier crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Cossiba Victorine G. was born on May 02, 1965 in Bopa in Benin. Victorine is married to Felix Amoussou a businessman. The couple have two school aged children. Victorine lives with their children in Cococodji, not far from Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Victorine has lived in this neighborhood for about 5 years. Together, the couple support the needs of their family. Victorine has not attended school but has studied the hair dressing trade. Vistorine has practiced this trade for 4 years. She also sells products from her salon such as cosmetics, jewelery, hair pieces and fabrics. Victorine buys her products from Lome in Togo, a country neighboring Benin and also from Dantokpa, the international market in Benin. To strengthen her business and better satisfy the needs of her clientele, Victorine is requesting this first loan from ALIDe.

Translated from French by David Gibbons, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 3 cartons of cosmetics, 2 dozen hair pieces, 15 pieces of fabric and jewelery

loans.name: Nile Group 2, Lugazi

texts.en: Rossette O. is a widow with six children, all still in school as she takes care of two additional dependents. She is a hard-working lady with a farming business consisting of plantations and a kraal (livestock enclosure) with cows that give her milk for sale. She says that at the moment, she has a small piece of land with which to expand her farm, and her goal is to acquire more land for continued expansion. She works from Bujowari and is able to make 280,000/= as weekly profits and would like this to expand further to be able to pay school fees for her children with ease.  Rossette, who would also like to construct her own rentals for a monthly income, is requesting a loan to be able to buy more cows for her farm.

loans.use: To buy another cow for farm expansion.

loans.name: Kaï

texts.fr: M. Kaï est née en 1965 à Djidja au Bénin. Kaï vit depuis 9 ans à Bazounkpa non loin de Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Kaï est mariée à AFANSSINOU Coffi, un transitaire, et est mère de quatre enfants. Tous les enfants sont scolarisés et vivent ensemble avec leurs parents à Bazounkpa. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Kaï n’a pas été à l’école, mais a appris la coiffure. Kaï exerce ce métier depuis cinq ans. A côté de cela, Kaï vend des mèches et des produits cosmétiques dans son atelier. C’est à Lomé au Togo, Etat voisin du Bénin, et aussi à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Kaï s’approvisionne. C’est la première fois que Kaï sollicite un crédit auprès de ALIDé, crédit qui lui servira à renforcer son activité afin de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Kai M. was born in 1965 at Djidja in Benin. Hai has lived in Bazounkpa, not far from Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin since she was 9 years old. Kai is maried to Coffi Afanssinou a transient worker. She is the mother of 4 children. All of her children attend school and live with their parents in Bazounkpa. The couple support the needs of their family. Kai never attended school, but learned to be a hair dresser. She has practiced her trade for 5 years. She also sells hair pieces and cosmetic products from her salon. Kai buys her supplies at Lome in Togo, a country neighboring Benin and from Dantokpa, the international market in Benin. This is the first loan that Kai has requested from ALIDe and will be used to strengthen her business and better satisfy the needs of her clientele.

Translated from French by David Gibbons, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 2 dozen hair pieces and 3 cartons of cosmetic products

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Loan to strengthen their businesses.

loans.name: Rosalie Viviane

texts.fr: D. Rosalie Viviane est née en 1979 à Lalo au Bénin. Mariée à AGBO Jacques, un revendeur de pièces détachées, Rosalie Viviane est mère de six enfants. Tous les enfants ne sont pas scolarisés. Rosalie Viviane vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari à Hevié, à quelques kilomètres de Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Il y a cinq ans environs que Rosalie Viviane vit dans ce quartier. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Rosalie Viviane n’a pas été à l’école. Afin d’aider son mari, Rosalie Viviane vend depuis trois ans environs, des bois de chauffage à son domicile. Rosalie Viviane mène comme activité secondaire, la vente de maïs. C’est dans les forêts du Bénin et à Adja au Mono (Bénin), que Rosalie Viviane s’approvisionne. Rosalie Viviane voudrait augmenter son capital et agrandir un peu plus son activité. C’est pourquoi Rosalie Viviane sollicite un premier crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Rosalie Viviane D. was born in 1979 in Lalo in Benin. Married to Jacques Agbo, a reseller of used parts, Rosalie Viviane is the mother of six children. Not all of the children attend school. Rosalie Viviane lives together with her children and husband in Havie, several kilometers from Cotonou, the economic captal of Benin. Rosalie Viviane has lived in this neighborhood for 5 years. Together, the couple support the needs of their family.Rosalie Viviane has not attended school. For the past three years she has assisted her husband with selling firewood from their home. As a second business, Rosalie Viviane sells corn. She acquires her supplies of wood from the forests around Adja in Benin. She would like to increase the size of her business. For this reason she is requesting this, her first loan from ALIDe.

Translated from French by David Gibbons, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy three truck loads of firewood

loans.name: Alinyikira Group, Central

texts.en:
N. Janat is the leader of her group in Mutundwe. She is 48 years old and married with seven children ages 16 to 30, with five of them at the University.  She also takes care of four orphans. 

She has had a retail shop for five years and a poultry business for a long time and manages to make 230,000 UGX as a weekly profit. 

Janat says that she is so friendly to her customers that it makes them draw money from their pockets into hers and her personality has also won her many genuine friends. She hopes for her two businesses to expand so that she and her family are more prosperous. Although her husband has his own job as a taxi driver, they work hand in hand to ensure that everything is okay. 

She needs a loan to help restock her retail shop and purchase more chicken feed, as well as buying more day old layers to produce more eggs.

loans.use: Restocking her shop with more goods and booking day old chicks for her farm's expansion.

loans.name: Rescate Group

texts.es:
Costura de polleras, tejido de prendas de vestir, producción de muebles y venta de fruta, son los diversos negocios de las integrantes del grupo Rescate que pertenece al Centro Focal German Busch, un ejemplo claro es Irma Q. de 22 años que trabaja hace 1 año costurando prendas de vestir y desea fortalecer su negocio comprando tela, otro ejemplo es Ema A. de 40 años, que desea iniciar un nuevo negocio como la  venda de fruta.
Los 8 integrantes de Rescate están esperanzados en mejorar sus negocios y por lo tanto mejorar su calidad de vida para ellas y sus familias.
texts.en:
Sewing, weaving, furniture making, and fruit sales are the diverse businesses of the members of the Rescate group of the German Busch regional center of Pro Mujer.

A good example is Irma Q., 22 years old, who has been working for the last year making clothing and wants to build her business by buying cloth. Another example is Ema A., 40 years old, who wants to start a new business selling fruit.

The eight members of Rescate are hopeful they can improve their businesses thus improve the quality of life for themselves and their families.

Translated from Spanish by jeffrey hersk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase raw materials and merchandise

loans.name: Yvette

texts.fr: M. Yvette est née vers 1980 à Aplahoué au Bénin. Mariée à SOSSOU Georges, un transporteur, Yvette est mère de trois enfants. Yvette a un autre enfant à charge, en plus de ses enfants. Tous les enfants ne sont pas scolarisés. La famille vit à Akossavié à Hevié (non loin de Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin) depuis trois ans. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Yvette n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Il y a environs deux ans que Yvette vend du maïs et de haricot au marché de Cococodji, à quelques kilomètres de Cotonou, et aussi à son domicile. Yvette s’approvisionne à Adja au Mono (Bénin). C’est la première fois que Yvette sollicite un crédit auprès de ALIDé, en vue de renforcer son activité et de mieux répondre à la demande de sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Yvette M. was born around 1980 in Aplahoué in Benin. She is married to Georges SOSSOU, a truck driver, and is the mother of three. Yvette supports another child, in addition to her own children. All the children lack schooling.

The family has been living in Akossavié Hevié (not far from Cotonou, Benin's economic capital) for the past three years. The couple shares the support for the family. Yvette has not attended school.

For approximately two years, she has been selling corn and beans at the Cococodji market, a few kilometers from Cotonou, and also from her home. Yvette gets her supplies from Adja in the Mono province (Benin). This is the first time she has applied for a loan with ALIDé, with the aim of reinforcing her activity and becoming more responsive to her customer's requests.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy three bags of corn and one bag of beans.

loans.name: Flor De Maria

texts.en:
Flor has two children who are both in school. Flor has a hardware store. She began working as a manager for her brother, and then he sold the store to her. She continues to sell fasteners, sandpaper, nails, etc. 

Flor will use this loan to restock her inventory. She says that the business has changed little by little because of the loans that she has received from Fundación León 2000. Her dream is for her son to receive his degree and be able to find work in his field, and her goal is to continue with her business. Flor is worried about her son making poor life decisions and getting involved with the wrong kind of people.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Egnonnamou Sylvie

texts.fr: H. Egnonnamou Sylvie est née en 1985 à Lama Kara au Togo, Etat voisin du Bénin. Mariée à DOSSA Olivier un gendarme, Sylvie n’a pas encore d’enfant. Sylvie vit à Cotonou, depuis environs 6 ans. Sylvie n’a fait que le cours primaire. Pour faire face à ses besoins, Sylvie vend depuis près de trois ans, des tissus, des chaussures, des sacs à main, etc. de façon ambulante. Sylvie s’approvisionne à Lomé au Togo, et aussi à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Sylvie a obtenu une fois de crédit à ALIDé, et a bien remboursé ce crédit. Sylvie désire agrandir davantage son activité pour mieux satisfaire sa clientèle. C’est la raison pour laquelle Sylvie sollicite un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Egnonnamou Sylvie H. was born in 1985 in Lama Kara in Togo, a country neighbouring Benin. Married to Olivier DOSSA - a policeman - she has no children yet. Sylvie has been living in Cotonou for the past six years. She only completed primary education. To meet her needs, Sylvie has been an itinerant vendor for the past three years, selling fabrics, shoes, handbags, etc. She gets her supplies from Lomé in Togo, as well as from Dantokpa, Benin's international market. She once before obtained a loan from ALIDé, which she fully reimbursed. Sylvie wants to increase her business to better satisfy her customers, which is why she requested a second loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy five pieces of cloth, one dozen pairs of shoes, five handbags

loans.name: Jane's Group

texts.en:
N. Jane is a widow with four grown children. She takes care of her grandchildren and orphans. 

She is a strong and hard-working lady with a bar business selling beers.  She says that she started her business using a loan and the loans still work well for her, except for the debtors that fail to pay. She is able to make 300,000 UGX as a monthly profit and this is due to her available stock and good bookkeeping. 

She needs to become more prosperous and self-sustaining now that she is getting much older. Jane Mary needs a loan to stock more beers that will bring in more profits for the season and the months to come.

loans.use: Stocking more beers for resale.

loans.name: Maritza Isabel

texts.en:
For ten years Maritza has had her business. She sells cooked beans which she makes in her home and sells in the central market of Chinandega very early in the morning.

Maritza will use this loan to buy products to support her business like beans and wood for her stove. Her aspirations are to continue to expand her business and improve her household.

Maritza is married and her husband works at a local factory. They have two children, 16 and 18, who are both in high school.

loans.use: To buy products to support her business like beans and wood for her stove

loans.name: 14 De Diciembre Group

texts.es:
Claudia C. de 28 años vende refrescos en la puerta de su casa, Vety H. de 27 años  vende comida en su domicilio hace 7 años, así como ellas, las demás integrantes de 14 de diciembre  que pertenecen al  Centro Focal German Busch venden  juguetes, plásticos y costura de chamarras.
Todas necesitan el préstamo para comprar mercadería, productos y materia prima y mejorar la calidad de sus productos, así como la atención a sus clientes ya que están concientes de que existe mucha competencia en el mercado.
texts.en:
Claudia C. is 28 years old. She sells soft drinks from the door of her house. Vety H. is 27 years old. She has sold food from her home for seven years. Like them, the members of 14 de Diciembre that belong to the German Busch Center sell toys, plastic products and sew jackets. They all need the loan to purchase merchandise, products and raw materials. Also, to improve the quality of their products as well as customer service since they are aware that there is a lot of competition in the marketplace.

Translated from Spanish by Ellen Donohue, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: PURCHASE OF INGREDIENTS AND MERCHANDISE

loans.name: Florence

texts.fr: K. Florence est née le 23 Septembre 1975 à Djidja au Bénin. Florence vit depuis environs 6 ans à Akossavié à Hevié (quelques kilomètres de Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin). Florence est mariée à NOUMONVI Alexandre, un revendeur, et est mère de quatre enfants. Tous les enfants sont scolarisés. Florence vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari à Hevié. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Florence n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Pour satisfaire ses besoins, Florence vend divers produits (lait, conserves, pâtes alimentaires, sucre, savons, riz, maïs, etc.) et aussi des boissons dans sa boutique size à Hevié. C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin que Florence s’approvisionne. Florence sollicite pour la première fois un crédit auprès de ALIDé, en vue d’agrandir davantage son activité et de répondre à la demande de plus en plus nombreuse de sa clientèle. Florence ambitionne ouvrir plus tard, une seconde boutique pour vendre ses articles.
texts.en:
Florence Zazotti was born September 23, 1975 in Djidja, Bénin. Florence has lived in Akossavié a Hevié for about 6 years (some kilometers from Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin). She is married to Alexandre Noumonvi, a reseller, and has four children. All of her children are in school. Florence lives with her children and husband in Hevié. Together, the couple supports the family. Florence did not go to school. To make a living, she sells various products (milk, preserves, pastas, sugar, soap, rice, maize, drinks etc.) in her store in Hevié. She stocks up on supplies in Dantokpa, the international market of Bénin.

Florence is asking for her first loan from ALIDé in order to expand her business and respond to the demands of her growing clientele. Florence dreams of some day opening a second store to sell her goods.

Translated from French by Kelly Percival, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of three cartons of milk boxes, two sacks of rice, preserves and two cartons of sugar

loans.name: Abejitas De Collpani Group

texts.es:
“Abejitas de Collpani” es un grupo de 9 señoras que pertenecen al Centro Focal Collpani, así, Paulina S. es la Presidenta, como Tesorera está Mauricio E. y como Secretaria de Actas es  Alicia M., las tres organizan a sus compañeras para llevar adelante su reunión, guiados por un orden del día.
Todas tienen diferentes negocios de comercialización, es decir, compara y venta de productos, producción y servicio y necesitan una vez más el crédito para invertir en sus negocios y generar ingresos para sus familias, además a ellas les gusta el consultorio porque tienen la oportunidad de cuidar su salud y la de su familia.
texts.en:
“Abejitas de Collpani” (the little bees of Collpani) is a group of 9 women who belong to the Focal Center Collpani. Paulina S. is the President, Mauricia E. is the Treasurer, and Alicia M. the Recording Secretary. The three organize their companions to carry on the meetings according to the daily agenda. All have different businesses: buying and selling products, production and services. They need another loan to help with their businesses and to generate income for their families. Besides they like the office because there they have the opportunity to take care of their health and that of their families.

Translated from Spanish by Miriam Palacio, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy merchandise and raw materials

loans.name: Felicia

texts.en:
Felicia A. is married and has four children. She has received senior high education.

Felicia is a hairdresser who owns a beauty salon. She sells assorted wigs and bush meat at Akotoyir near Abura, a suburb in Cape Coast, which she has been doing for the past four years. Her husband is a contractor. Felicia uses her income to support her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills.

Felicia will use the loan to purchase hair attachments, weave-ons (hair extensions) and bush meat for resale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Felicia plans to save to educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase hair attachments, weave-ons and bush meat for resale

loans.name: Dédé

texts.en: Mrs. M. owns a general grocery store in Agoé. She has been running her business since 2000. Her husband is a taxi driver and they have 2 children. This will be her first loan with WAGES. She will use the funds to purchase rice, oil, spaghetti, and a variety of shoes to resell. She plans on repaying her loan in installments over the course of the next 12 months. This loan will help her maintain a profitable and prosperous business.

loans.use: Various grocery products

loans.name: Gyenvudde Group, Lugazi

texts.en: N. Milly is the leader of her group in Lugazi. She is a widow with six children between the ages of 20 and 32. She takes care of orphans and mostly grandchildren. Milly has been a fishmonger from Buvuma for 15 years. She says that her business is affected by the scarcity of fish and a lot of competition although she survives with the profits she makes. She is grateful for her loans because she has been able to pay her children’s school fees. She would like to become a wholesale supplier of fish to companies and also she would like to build a house for her family. Milly needs a loan to be able to buy more fish to sell to her customers. These days, fish are scarce yet the market is big.

loans.use: Buying more fish for resale.

loans.name: Olivia Del Socorro

texts.en: Olivia has a clothing sales business that she runs out of her house. She also sells her items by peddling. She will use this loan to buy merchandise like clothing, shoes, cosmetics, perfumes and other items that her customers request. Her aspirations are to continue to increase her business and to make it more like a store. Olivia’s husband works as a distiller in a local liquor factory and they have two children. Their children’s ages are eight and four and both are in school, although the four year old is only in preschool. Olivia has had her business for eleven years and has maintained an excellent credit history with Fundación León 2000.

loans.use: Working capital.

loans.name: Bernadette Baï

texts.fr: A. Bernadette Baï est née le 20 Août 1977 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Bernadette Baï vit à Cococodji, non loin de Cotonou, depuis environs 8 ans. Mariée à TCHIAKPE Zakari, un commerçant, Bernadette Baï est mère de deux enfants, tous scolarisés. Bernadette Baï vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Bernadette Baï a arrêté l’école au cours secondaire, et a appris ensuite la coiffure. Bernadette Baï exerce ce métier depuis 5 ans déjà. Bernadette Baï vend également des mèches et des produits cosmétiques dans son atelier. C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin que Bernadette Baï s’approvisionne. Bernadette Baï a obtenu une fois de crédit à ALIDé, et a bien remboursé le prêt. Bernadette Baï voudrait élever le niveau de son activité et satisfaire davantage sa clientèle. C’est pourquoi Bernadette Baï sollicite un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
A.
