Bernadette Baï was born on August 20, 1977 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin.  She has been living in Cococodji, not far from Cotonou, for about eight years.  Married to TCHIAKPE Zakari, a merchant, she is the mother of two children who are both in school.  She lives together with her children and husband.  The couple provides for the family jointly.  Bernadette Baï had dropped out of secondary school and then learned how to style hair.  She has been working at this trade for about five years already.  She also sells hair extensions and cosmetic products in her salon.  She stocks up from Dantokpa, the international market of Benin.  She once obtained a loan from ALIDé and has repaid it.  She would like to raise her level of business and to satisfy her customers more.  This is why she's requesting a second loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying 3 boxes of cosmetics and 5 dozen hair extensions

loans.name: Cruz Carmelina

texts.es:
El banco comunal Mujeres Floreciendo está conformado por mujeres que luchan día a día demostrando que pueden ser más valiosas de lo que muchas personas creen y están dispuestas a salir adelante con sus familias. Este banco se inició en Cuenca,  ciudad hermosa llena de tradiciones y leyendas, dueña de una  belleza natural incomparable.
 
La señora Cruz L.  es socia del banco comunal Mujeres Floreciendo hace cinco años,  los préstamos recibidos le han  beneficiado para crear su propio negocio y tener estabilidad económica, recuerda que fue una amiga quien la incentivo a que forme parte del banco comunal. 

Cruz tiene 55 años de edad,  vive en la parroquia Pacha con su  esposo que trabaja como guardia de seguridad y sus dos hijos de 28 y 26 años,   su primer hijo trabaja y le ayuda con los gastos del hogar.  Ella se dedica a la preparación de bocaditos como tamales, quimbolitos, humitas y  dulces  de toda clase, lleva 17 años  realizando esta actividad que la aprendió por necesidad.   También se dedica a la venta de ropa a crédito, sus ventas las realiza recorriendo toda la ciudad  y a sus vecinos de la  comunidad.
 
Con el préstamo solicitado a  la fundación  va a comprar los ingredientes como harina, manteca, aceite, mantequilla y más productos para elaborar sus bocaditos y otra parte en   la compra de ropa para incrementar su negocio. 

Su sueño es viajar a New York.
texts.en:
The communal bank Mujeres Floreciendo is made up of women that fight day to day to prove that they can be braver than many people think. They are ready to get ahead with their families. This bank began in Cuenca, a beautiful city full of traditions and legends with an incomparable natural beauty. Mrs. Cruz L. has been a member of the Mujeres Floreciendo communal bank for five years. The loans she has received have helped her create her own business and achieve financial stability. Remember it was a friend who encouraged her to become part of the communal bank. Cruz is 55 years old. She lives in the Pacha parish with her husband who works as a security guard, and her two children that are 28 and 26 years old. Her first son works and helps her with the household expenses. She works preparing snacks like tamales, quimbolitos, humitas and all kinds of sweets. She has been doing this job for 17 years. She learned it due to necessity. She also sells clothes on credit. She makes her sales by going all over the city and her neighbors in the community. With the loan she is going to buy ingredients such as flour, lard, oil, butter and more products to make her snacks and another part to buy clothes to grow her business. Her dream is to travel to New York.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Haynes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase flour, oil, lard, butter, etc.

loans.name: Maruja

texts.es:
Nuestra socia MARUJA tiene 53 años, es divorciada, es padre y madre para sus tres hijos. Milagros tiene 25 años y estudia obstetricia, Yashira tiene 19 años y estudia contabilidad y Xiomara tiene 19 años y estudia ciencias políticas. La socia es docente cesante y actualmente se dedica a la venta y distribución de cerveza. La socia acomodo una parte de la casa para abrir su tienda donde almacena y vende la cerveza. La socia nos cuenta que al principio le iba muy bien vendía 300 cajas por día pero por su barrio abrieron tiendas de venta de cerveza y le hacen la competencia. Actualmente bajo el negocio y vende aproximadamente 100 cajas por día lo cual nuestra socia opto por abrir otro negocio de venta de ropa. Ya son varios años que tiene de venta de cerveza y le ha ido más o menos, gracias a todo el empeño que pone en su trabajo. Nuestra socia es una madre trabajadora y emprendedora que saca adelante a su familia a pesar de las dificultades de la vida. La socia requiere el préstamo para comprar más cerveza y así de esta forma aumentar el capital del negocio.  
 
La socia pertenece al Banco Comunal “FUENTE DE VIDA” de la Asociación Arariwa de la ciudad de Cusco. Antiguamente, fue la capital del Imperio Inca y una de las ciudades más importantes del Virreinato del Perú. Declarada Patrimonio de la Humanidad y capital arqueológica de América 

La socia se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Our group member MARUJA is 53 years old and divorced. She is father and mother to her three children. Milagros is 25 years old and studies obstetrics. Yashira is 19 years old and studies accounting. Xiomara is 19 years old and studies political science. The group member is an unemployed teacher and currently works selling and distributing beer. The group member fixed a part of the house to open her store where she stores and sells the beer. The group member tells us that at first it was going well and she sold 300 cases per day. But they opened stores that sell beer in her neighborhood so now there is competition. Currently business has declined and she sells 100 cases per day. This is why the group member opted to open another business selling clothes. It’s been various years since she’s been selling beer and it has more or less gone well, thanks to all her hard work that she puts into her job. Our group member is a working mother, an entrepreneur that is getting ahead with her family amidst life’s difficulties. The group member needs a loan to purchase more beer and this way increase the business capital. The group member belongs to the “FUENTE DE VIDA” Communal Bank of the Arariwa Association of the city of Cusco. In the past it was the capital of the Inca Empire and one of the most important cities of the Vice Royalty of Peru, declared a World Heritage and the archeological capital of America. The group member is thankful for the opportunity given this way and promises to meet the corresponding payments on schedule.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Haynes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: The group member needs the loan to purchase more beer and this way increase the business capital.

loans.name: Thérèse

texts.fr: G. Thérèse est née en 1947. Thérèse vit depuis 7 ans environs à Djissoukpa, non loin de Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. C’est une veuve, ayant à sa charge deux enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Thérèse vit seule avec ses enfants et supporte seule les charges de la famille. Thérèse n’a pas été à l’école. Pour satisfaire ses besoins et ceux de ses enfants, Thérèse vend du maïs et aussi de l’akassa (aliment local fait à base d’amidon de maïs). Thérèse mène cette activité à son domicile, et aussi par le système de distribution. C’est à Adja au Mono (Bénin) que Thérèse s’approvisionne. C’est la première fois que Thérèse sollicite un crédit auprès de ALIDé, afin de renforcer son activité pour mieux satisfaire sa clientèle.
texts.en:
G. Thérèse was born in 1947.  She has been living for about seven years in Djissoukpa, not far from Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin.  She is a widow with two children to support.  Both are in school.  She lives alone with her children and is the sole provider of the family.  Thérèse did not attend school.  To meet her needs and those of her children, she sells corn and also akassa (a local food made with cornstarch).  She operates this business in her home and also through the distribution system.  Adja, in Mono (Benin), is where she stocks up.  This is the first time that she has requested a loan from ALIDé for bolstering her business, so as to satisfy her customers more.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying 4 sacks of corn

loans.name: Nadezhda

texts.en:
Nadezhda is single. She runs her small business, selling retail household items, in the central market of her hometown of Melitopol. Nadezhda has been working in this sphere of business for over 11 years. Her market venture has benefited greatly from lending assistance. Currently, her turnover capital amounts to 15,000 Grivnyas. Her profit is about 8,000 Grivnyas a month.  

Nadezhda is seeking a 15,000 Grivnya loan to purchase additional merchandise and generate additional income as a result. She is hoping to invest a portion of the increased income in improving her living conditions and towards the purchase of necessary domestic appliances.

loans.use: To increase amounts of assorted merchandise.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary W. is married and has five dependents. She has no educational background. Mary sells fresh cassava, pepper and plantain at Abura market, a suburb in cape coast, which she has been doing for the past two years. Her husband is a cleaner. Mary uses her income to support her husband in the education of her children.  Mary will use the loan to buy more cassava, plantain and peppers to sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, Mary plans to save to build a house.

loans.use: Mary will use the loan to buy more cassava, plantain and pepper to sell.

loans.name: Kakola Group, Lugazi

texts.en: Constance N. is a hardworking married lady with five children ranging in age from 20 – 9 years, all in school. Previously a farmer, for the past two years Constance has operated a boutique in Katoogo.  She says that there is a lot of competition in the business which requires her to work harder for increased outcomes. Able to make 60,000/= as profits per week which helps with the education of her children, Constance hopes, with the help of a loan, to expand her boutique further with more quality clothes.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for resale.

loans.name: Akouavi

texts.fr: K. Akouavi est née le 20 Mai 1953 à Ouidah, ville historique du Bénin. Mariée à OGOULOLA Louis, un maçon,  Akouavi est mère de deux enfants, tous scolarisés. Akouavi a un autre enfant à charge, en plus de ses enfants. Akouavi vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari à Cocotomey, non loin de Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Il y a environs 6 ans que Akouavi vit dans ce quartier. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. Akouavi n’a fait que le cours primaire. Akouavi vend depuis plus de 5 ans, des produits divers (conserves, savons, bougies, pâtes alimentaires, petits pois, piles, sardines, huile d’arachide, etc.) dans sa boutique size à son domicile. C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Akouavi s’approvisionne. Akouavi a obtenu une fois de crédit à ALIDé et l’a bien remboursé. Akouavi désire augmenter son capital afin de compléter le stock de ses produits. C’est la raison pour laquelle Akouavi sollicite un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
K. Akouavi was born on May 20, 1953 in Ouidah, a historic city of Benin.  She is married to OGOULOLA Louis, a mason, and is the mother of two children who are both in school.  She has another child to support in addition to her own.  She lives together with her children and husband in Cocotomey, not far from Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin.  She has been living in this district for about six years.  The couple jointly ensures that family expenses are covered.  Akouavi has attended only primary school.  For five years, she has been selling various goods (canned foods, soaps, candles, pasta, peas, batteries, sardines, peanut oil, etc.) in her store in her home.  Dantokpa, the international market of Benin, is where she stocks up.  She once obtained a loan from ALIDé and has repaid it.  She would like to augment her capital in order to round out her stock of goods.  This is the reason why she's requesting a second loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying 2 boxes of canned tomatoes, a box of soap, 2 boxes of pasta, 1 container of peanut oil

loans.name: Tatyana

texts.en:
Tatyana is married with two grown children. She has a degree in economics. Tatyana is a small market vendor from Dneprorudnyi, where she owns a clothing-sales business in one of the local markets. She owns a nice, spacious kiosk/store, which makes it very comfortable for her customers to try on different clothing items. Tatyana has been in this trade for over 12 years. Presently, she has 60,000 Grivnyas worth of inventory.  

Tatyana is requesting a loan of 15,000 Grivnyas to increase the assorted inventory she offers for sale in her kiosk. She is planning to consistently develop her venture and see its further stable growth in the future.

loans.use: Increase her working capital

loans.name: Casimira

texts.es:
El banco comunal Mujeres Floreciendo está conformado por mujeres que luchan día a día demostrando que pueden ser más valiosas de lo que muchas personas creen y están dispuestas a salir adelante con sus familias. Este banco se inició en Cuenca,  ciudad hermosa llena de tradiciones y leyendas, dueña de una  belleza natural incomparable.
 

La señora Casimira P. es socia activa del banco comunal Mujeres Floreciendo desde hace 18 años,  la facilidad de pago y los múltiples beneficios que recibe así como el deseo de superación la incentivaron a formar parte del banco comunal.

Nuestra socia  vive en la comunidad el Paraíso en la parroquia El Valle, tiene 60 años y se encuentra divorciada hace 20 porque  su esposo la maltrataba física y sicológicamente, de ésta relación tormentosa concibió trece  hijos de los cuales tres fallecieron debido al maltrato, no recuerda las edades de sus hijos vivos pero sí que nueve de ellos  ya son casados y tienen su propia familia, sólo le acompaña  su ultima hija que ya está comprometida y  dos nietos  de 15 y 9  debido a que su madre  viajó  al extranjero para cuidar su integridad física puesto su esposo la había amenazado de muerte, viven arrendando porque no tienen casa propia.

Casimira se dedica a la venta de granos tiernos,  verduras y plantas de algunas hortalizas en la feria libre de la ciudad,  también vende animales que los cría  para el sacrificio, su horario de trabajo es de 6am a 6pm, está satisfecha con los logros conseguidos.

Con el nuevo préstamo solicitado va a comprar arveja, fréjol, tomate, cebolla y más verduras así como materiales para la  construcción  de una chanchera  para iniciar con su nuevo negocio de crianza de cerdos para la venta.

Su sueño es poder tener una casa propia.
texts.en:
The Mujeres Floreciendo comunal bank is made up of women who fight every day showing that they can be more valuable than what most people think, and are willing to take their families forward. This bank was started in Cuenca, a beautiful city full of traditions and legends, with an incomparable natural beauty. Miss Casimira P. has been an active member of the Mujeres Floreciendo communal bank for the past 18 years; the easiness of payments and the multiple benefits she receives and her wishes for fulfillment created the incentive to be a part of the communal bank. Our partner lives in the El Paraiso community in the El Valle parish; she is 60 years old and has been divorced for 20 years because her husband abused her physically and psychologically. Out of this tumultuous relationship she conceived 13 children, three of which passed away due to the physical abuses. She doesn't remember the ages of her living children, but she knows that nine of them are married already and have their own families. Her only company is her last daughter who is already engaged, and two grandsons of 15 and 9 because their mother had to go abroad when her husband threatened to kill her. They rent a home because they don't own a house. Casimira is devoted to the sale of grain, vegetables, and plants from some patches in the free market of the city, and also sells animals that are raised for sacrifice. Her work schedule is from 6am to 6pm. She is satisfied with her accomplishments. With this new loan she will purchase peas, beans, tomato, onion and other vegetables as well as construction materials from a pig farm to start with her new pig business. Her dream is to have her own home.

Translated from Spanish by Esteban Riojas, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase peas, beans, tomato, onion and other vegetables as well as construction materials from a pig farm

loans.name: Denny Cecilia

texts.es:
Denny Gómez de 27 años de edad, vive en la zona de la Perimetral en Guayaquil, tiene una casa de caña y solo tiene un servicio básico que es el agua, Denny comenzó su negocio para poderle ayudar a su esposa y pensó en ponerle una mini tienda.  

Denny trabaja desde las 07h00 hasta las 22h00pm en su tienda tiene caramelos compra la funda a $ 1.50, comprar a $ 0.20 los papel higiénico c/u, compra pañales a $ 0.10, colas etc. Una de las mayores complicaciones que tiene en su negocio son los ladrones, su esposo le ayuda con los gastos familiares siendo obrero en construcciones tiene 3 hijos uno de 7 años, 3 años y 1 año el mayor estudia en una escuela fiscal.

Con el préstamo quiere comprar 50 fundas de caramelos, 100 pañales, 50 colas. En el futuro quiere arreglar su casa para construirla de cemento y poder así tener mas espacio para su negocio.
texts.en:
Denny Gómez is 27 years old. She lives in the area called "The Perimetral en Guayaquil." She has a house made of sugar cane reeds and only has basic services -- running water. Denny began her business to be able to help her husband, and she decided to have a mini store. Denny works from 7 a.m. until 10 p.m. in her store. She has sweets and buys wrappers at $1.50, to buy toilet paper at $ 0.20 each one, she buys diapers at $ 0.10, colas, etc. One of the biggest challenges she has in her business is thievery. Her husband helps her with the family expenses as a construction worker. They have 3 children, 7 years old, 3 years and a one year' old. The eldest studies in a financial school. With the loan, she wants to buy 50 sweets wrappers, 100 diapers, and 50 colas. In the future she wants to rebuild her house of cement and be able make more space for her business.

Translated from Spanish by Jo Longnecker, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: sweets, diapers and colas

loans.name: Bernadette

texts.fr: D. Bernadette est née le 16 Décembre 1965 à Savi Houeyiho au Bénin. Bernadette vit depuis environs 8 ans à Cococodji, non loin de Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à GBAGUIDI Guy, Bernadette est mère de quatre enfants, tous scolarisés. La famille vit ensemble à Cococodji. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Bernadette n’a pas été à l’école. Il y a sept ans environs que Bernadette vend des condiments (tomates fraîches, tomates en boîtes, piment écrasé, poivre, ails, oignons, etc.) et aussi des légumes au marché de Cococodji. C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Bernadette s’approvisionne. Bernadette a obtenu une fois de crédit à ALIDé, crédit qu’elle a bien remboursé. En vue d’élever le niveau de son activité et d’accroître son chiffre d’affaire, Bernadette sollicite un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Bernadette D. was born on December 16, 1965 in Savi Houeyiho, in Benin. Bernadette has been living for 8 years in Cococodji, near Cotonou, Benin's economic capital. Married to Guy GBAGUIDI, Bernadette is the mother of four children, that are all schooled. The family lives together in Cococodji. Together, the couple bears the family's expenses. Bernadette has not been schooled. For the past seven years, Bernadette has been selling condiments (fresh tomatoes, canned tomatoes, crushed pepper, pepper, garlic, onions, etc.) as well as fresh vegetables at the Cococodji's market. She buys her products at Dantokpa, Benin's international market. Bernadette has already obtained a first loan from ALIDé that she has fully repaid. In order to increase her activity and revenue, Bernadette is requesting a second loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by caroline Mrejen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of baskets of fresh tomatoes, oignons and peppers

loans.name: Abena

texts.en:
Abena E. sells corn (a cereal that most Ghanaian dishes are prepared from, such at porridge, banku and so on) as a hawker in Abura on the Cape Coast. Abena has no educational background. She is married and has five dependents. Her husband is a harvester. 

Abena has been selling corn for the past two years. She supports her husband to educate the children and pay utility bills. Her loan will be used to buy more maize in larger quantities to sell. She hopes to use the new profits from her business as savings for expanding her cocoa farm.

loans.use: Her loan will be used to buy more maize in larger quantities to sell.

loans.name: Nakazadde Group, Lugazi

texts.en:
Margaret N. is a hardworking lady. She is married with four children ranging in age from 4 to 11, all in the primary section of school. She takes care of her siblings. Margaret has had a retail shop in Nakazadde for eight years and although her business has a lot of competition, she is able to make about 150,000 Ugandan shillings as profits a week. 

In the future, Margaret plans to become a wholesaler to make more profits to be able to educate her children at the best of school for a much brighter future. Margaret needs a loan to be able to restock her retail shop with more goods to increase sales.

loans.use: Restocking her retail shop with more goods

loans.name: Gregoria Lurdes

texts.es:
"Doña Gregoria Lurdes, tiene 37 años de edad y vive en casa propia en la zona de Sopocachi, tiene 3 hijos que estudian en colegio y se encuentra casada con don Elmer Julio, el mismo que trabaja como chofer propietario de un Bus en un sindicado de la ciudad y colabora con los gastos de la casa; doña Gregoria tiene como actividad la tienda de barrio donde vende productos de primera necesidad, la misma que se encuentra ubicada en la casa de la madre ubicada en la av. buenos aires .

El credito solicitado es para la compra de mercaderia por temporada de navidad, ya que quiere surtir la tienda ya que en esta epoca navideña la sra. gregoria incrementa su venta.
texts.en:
Gregoria Lurdes is 37, and she lives in her own house in the Sopocachi area. She has three children who go to school. She is married to Elmer Julio. He works as a driver-owner of a bus in the city syndicate. He collaborates with the household expenses. Gregoria has a neighborhood store where she sells basic needs items. The business is located in her mother’s house on Buenos Aires Avenue. The loan she is asking for is to buy merchandise for the Christmas season. She wants to stock her store because Gregoria increases her sales during the Christmas season.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy merchandise to stock her store

loans.name: Rosario

texts.es:
Nuestra socia ROSARIO tiene 44 años, es viuda y hace 8 años que falleció su esposo. La socia es padre y madre para sus dos hijos. Cesar tiene 18 años y estudia Ingeniería de Sistema en la universidad y Geanella estudia en el colegio. La socia alterna sus actividades del hogar con la venta de Artesanías. La socia tiene una tienda de artesanía llamada “Charito” en el Aeropuerto “Velasco Astete” del Cusco donde vende chompas y cerámica de barro. Ya son 30 años que tiene el negocio y le ha ido muy bien, gracias a todo el empeño que pone en su trabajo. Nuestra socia es una madre trabajadora y emprendedora que desde niña trabajo a lado de su mamá y heredo el negocio. La socia requiere el préstamo para comprar más materiales para confeccionar más artesanía y chompas de lana de las mayorista que traen de la ciudad de Juliaca del departamento de Puno. 
 
La socia pertenece al Banco Comunal “FUENTE DE VIDA” de la Asociación Arariwa de la ciudad de Cusco.

Cusco antiguamente, fue la capital del Imperio Inca y una de las ciudades más importantes del Virreinato del Perú. Declarada Patrimonio de la Humanidad y capital arqueológica de América 

La socia se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Rosario is 44. She is a widow; her husband died eight years ago. She is father and mother to her two children. Cesar is 18 and is studying Systems Engineering in the university. Geanella is in school. Rosario alternates her activities between the household and selling handicrafts. She has a handcrafts store called “Charito” in the Valasco Astete airport in Cusco. She sells sweaters and ceramics made of clay. She has had the business for 30 years. It has gone very well for her thanks to all of the effort she puts into her work. She is an enterprising and hard-working mother, who worked at her mother’s side as a girl. She inherited the business. She needs the loan to buy more material to make more handicrafts and to buy more wool sweater from the wholesalers who bring them from the city of Juliaca in the Puno department. She belongs to the Fuente de Vida Communal Bank of the Arariwa Association in the city of Cusco. Cusco was the ancient capitol of the Inca Empire and one of the most important cities of the viceroyalty of Perú. It was declared the Patrimony of Humanity and the archeological capitol of America. She is grateful for the opportunity of the loan, and she promises to pay it on time.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy more materials to make more handicrafts and wool sweaters

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.es: La Señora Yolanda se dedica a la venta de abarrotes desde hace cinco años, ella vive en casa de familiares, todos los dias desde las 6:00 am hasta las 22:00 tiene su tienda abierta, tiene variedad de mercaderia desde gaseosas, galletas, dulces, fideos, azucar, leche, etc. productos que son primordiales para el hogar, ella piensa invertir el prestamo  en la compra de más productos puesto que por estas fiestas de fin de año es cuando más vende y necesita llenar su tienda con bebidas gaseosas, juguetes y otros que son solicitados en estas fechas.
texts.en:
Ms. Yolanda has been selling groceries for the past 5 years. She lives with her family members and every day from 6AM to 10PM she's at her store selling soft drinks, crackers, candy, noodles, sugar, mild, and other first necessity products. She is using the loan to buy more products since the holidays are coming up and her sales will increase. She needs to purchase fizzy drinks, toys and other things people look for at this time of the year.

Translated from Spanish by Mariana Dauwe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of products for reselling

loans.name: Batoma

texts.fr:
Madame  Batoma   Singaré  est âgée de 28 ans,  mariée  et mère de 4 enfants. Elle vit dans la famille paternelle de son mari avec plusieurs autres ménages dans le quartier Darsalam  près de l’hôpital régional  Famory Doumbia de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Batoma a laissé  les études en classe de 5ème année fondamentale (système éducatif Malien) pour mener des activités génératrices de revenus notamment le commerce. Elle débuta à côté de sa mère qui vendait du poisson. Après 5 ans passés auprès de cette dernière, elle continua seule la vente de poisson séché au marché Château depuis maintenant 5 ans. Elle jouit d’une grande réputation dans son lieu de vente et même dans son quartier. Elle reçoit fréquemment des commandes de Bamako et Kayes où elle a des clients.
Ses poissons soigneusement conservés à l’abri de mouches et moustiques.
Dans le souci de renforcer son commerce, elle fait recours à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso.  Elle est en relation avec cette dernière depuis 7 mois après avoir remboursé un 1er prêt individuel sans aucune difficulté. 
Elle compte utiliser ce prêt pour acheter, 200kgs de poissons séchés «wuludjéké », autrement appelé ‘’poisson chien’’. 
Elle s’approvisionne sur place à Ségou auprès des pêcheurs.
Madame Batoma   Singaré  vend, en gros, en détail, au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée  de femmes  et d’hommes. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 75 000FCFA, qui lui permettra de prendre en charge certaines dépenses familiales. 
Son ambition est d’avoir une maison à usage d’habitation.
texts.en:
Ms. Batoma Singaré is 28 years old, married, and the mother of four children.  She lives in her husband's paternal family with several other households in the Darsalam district, near the Famory Doumbia regional hospital of Ségou (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali).   Batoma left school in the 5th year of elementary school (education system of Mali) in order to work at generating an income, notably in commerce.  She started along side her mother, who used to sell fish.  After five years spent with her, Batoma continued on her own selling dried fish at the Château market, and she has been doing so for five years now.  She enjoys a great reputation in her sales area and even in her district.  She frequently received orders from Bamako and Kayes, where she has customers.  Her fish is neatly kept, protected from flies and mosquitoes.  Wanting to bolster her commerce, she turned toward Soro Yiriwaso, a micro-finance institution with which she has been associated for seven months after having repaid an initial individual loan without any problems at all.  She plans on using this new loan to buy 200 kg of wuludjéké dried fish, also called "dog fish".  She stocks up locally in Ségou from fishermen.  Batoma sells wholesale and retail, and she accepts cash and credit from customers composed of women and men.  She plans on realizing a monthly profit of 75,000 francs CFA, which will allow her to cover certain family expenses.  Her ambition is to have a house in which to live.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying dried fish

loans.name: Karla

texts.es:
Nuestra socia KARLA tiene 35 años, es conviviente y tiene dos hijos. Cynthia tiene tres años y Rodrigo tiene tres meses de nacido. La socia alterna sus actividades del hogar con la venta de víveres. La socia tiene un stand en el mercado “San Pedro” de la ciudad del Cusco. Ya son cuatro meses que tiene el negocio y le ha ido muy bien, gracias a todo el empeño que pone en su trabajo. Nuestra socia es una madre trabajadora y emprendedora que saca adelante a sus hijos. La socia requiere el préstamo para comprar más comestibles como arroz, azúcar, leche, fideos, aceite y muchas cosas más. 

La socia es natural de la ciudad del Cusco y pertenece al Banco Comunal “FUENTE DE VIDA” de la Asociación Arariwa. Cusco antiguamente, fue la capital del Imperio Inca y una de las ciudades más importantes del Virreinato del Perú. Declarada Patrimonio de la Humanidad y capital arqueológica de América 

La socia se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Karla is 35 years old and lives with her partner and their two children, Cynthia who is 3 years old and Rodrigo who is 3 months old. Karla balances her housewife activitives with her business selling first necessity products. She has a stand at the San Pedro market in Cusco, Peru. She's been doing this for four months and she's doing really well, thanks to all her effort and dedication to work. She is a hard working and entrepeneur mother that is always putting her children first. Karla is asking for this loan in order to buy more food products like rice, sugar, milk, crackers, oil and many other things. She is a local to Cusco and belongs to the Comunal Bank "Fuente de Vida'. She is thankful for having this opportunity and is committed to pay the loan back.

Translated from Spanish by Mariana Dauwe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of food products

loans.name: Julia Veronica

texts.es: La Señora Julia es un cliente nuevo que llega a la empresa por la promocion hecha por la zona de achumani, ella es madre soltera de dos pequeños, vive en anticretico y sostiene a su familia con una tienda de barrio que tambien la utiliza como snack por las noches, donde vende salchipapas y silpanchos, ya que a esas horas es el unico lugar donde se puede encontrar comida por las zona, la señora  tambien es propietaria de un minibus del cual recibe renta diaria. La señora julia al ver que su local no tiene el suficiente espacio ni la capacidad para atender la cantidad de clientes que  visitan el lugar decidio alquilar un cuarto que esta al frente de su actual negocio y equiparlo para poder atender mejor y a mas clientes poe eso solicito el prestamo para la compra de muebles y mercaderia.
texts.en:
Julia is a new client who comes to us thanks to the recuriting efforts made in the Achumani area. She is a single mother of two children. She lives under the "anticretico" (Anticretico is a transaction not available in the U.S. whereby a property owner requests a "loan" from you in exchange for housing, which must be paid back to you at the end of your contract. If your loan is not repaid, the property owner loses the property to you) modality and supports her family with a neighborhoold grocery store that at night she turns into a snack bar where she sells such typical dishes as "salchipapas" (a type of fast food that consists of thinly sliced pan-fried beef hot dogs or sausage and French fries, mixed together and served on a plate or in a paper cone, served with different sauces) and "silpanchos" (a schnitzel-style beef that is served with tomatoes, onions and a base layer of rice. It is often served with fried eggs on top.) At that time of night, this is the only place in the area where such dishes can be found. She also owns a minibus which provides her with a daily rental income. Julia, upon noting that her eatery lacked enough space to accommodate all the customers that came, decided to rent a room which is across the way from her current place of business and furnish it to better serve more customers. This is the reason behind the loan request to buy furniture and supplies.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy supplies and furniture.

loans.name: Maria Luisa

texts.es: Doña Maria Luisa es un cliente nuevo que se dedica a la venta D. accesorios para el hogar en una ferreteria como chapas, sockets, interruptores, tambien mangueras, balanzas,exprimidores manuales y el ultimo pedido que tiene es por una gran cantidad D. botas que ella los venD. por sacos que contienen 50 pares D. botas D. trabajo D. goma, la cliente realiza sus entregas en la ciudad D. Santa Cruz y Montero, ella trabaja ya hace 10 años con su mama  y el itinerario implica ir a desaguadero para proveerse D. toda la mercaeria posible, los dias domingo viaja con direccion a santa cruz con escala en cochabamba, los dias martes y miercoles se dedican a entregar y cobrar por la mercaderia, temprano en jueves retornan a la Paz para abrir su ferreteria y los dias viernes  va a la feria del desaguadero frontera con Peru. La señora tiene el Apoyo D. su esposo Jose Luis quien se comprometio con el apoyo a su esposa en el pago putual D. las cuotas, ya que el señor trabaja como distribuidor D. la ferreteria en achumani y tiene constantes pedidos por la zona D. chasquipamapa.
texts.en:
Ms. Maria Luisa is a new client who sells accessories, such as switch plate covers, light sockets, switches, also hoses, scales, and hand juicers in a hardware store. Her latest request has been for a large quantity of boots, which she sells in packs containing 50 pairs of rubber work boots to her customers in Santa Cruz and Montero. She’s been working with her mother for ten years and they travel to Desaguadero to see all available merchandise. On Sundays she goes to Santa Cruz and stops in Cohabamba. On Tuesdays and Wednesdays they deliver their merchandise and collect payment. They return to La Paz early on Thursdays to open the hardware store and on Fridays she goes to the marketplace on the Peruvian border. She has the support of her husband, Jose Luis, and they have both committed to repaying this loan on schedule. He works as a hardware distributor in Achumani and has many requests from the Chasquipamapa district.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Incremento de mercaderia

loans.name: Vasilina

texts.en: Vasilina is divorced with three children. She sells souvenirs and articles made of wood, skin and fur. Most of these articles are made by Ukrainian craftsmen. Vasilina has two business locations: one at a local market and the other in a small store where she rents space. She started her business six years ago. It is a unique business that even today has very little competition. This business is the only source of income for Vasilina and her three children. Vasilina would like to borrow 13,600 hryvnia to increase her assortment. She hopes to develop her business further and ultimately to help her children receive a college education.

loans.use: To  increase assortment of crafts

loans.name: Elsa

texts.es: La sra. Elsa tiene su tienda desde hace mucho tiempo en su casa ubicada en  zona de Pampahasi, es una tienda muy surtida y muy conocida por la zona, ella vive con sus hijos que están estudiando y con su esposo que trabaja en una entidad pública; es una cliente muy responsable, y conoce muy bien todo lo referido a su negocio, este crédito será invertido incrementando su mercaderia con la compra de bebidas para las fiestas de fin de año y comprará abarrotes para venderlos en la tienda.
texts.en:
Elsa has had her store in her house for a long time now. She is located in the Pampahasi area. It is a well-stocked and well-known store in the area. She lives with her children, who are students, and her husband, who works for a public entity. She is a very responsible client and knows her business well. This financing will be used to buy more stock items, especially beverages for the end-of-year festivities; she will also buy more grocery items to sell in her store.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase stock inventory.

loans.name: Meylin Eliette

texts.en:
Meylin is married and has three children between the ages of 14 and 19; they are all in school.

Her business is the sale of small food items like eggs, crackers, bread and ice cream. Meylin sells these items on foot. She started this business as a way to supplement her family's income when her husband wasn’t able to support the family with what he makes. Meylin says that her loans with Fundación León 2000 have helped her to improve her family's income and improve their household.

Meylin will use this loan to buy items like eggs and bread for resale. Meylin says that the challenge of her business is the difficulty of the quantity of eggs that she sells because she has to carry so many and the eggs will break if she cannot maintain her balance. Meylin dreams of being able to have her own motorcycle as it will help both her and her husband with their work.

loans.use: To buy items like eggs and bread for resale

loans.name: Lenuel

texts.en:
For fifteen years, Don Leunel has had a welding business. He was trained and educated in the trade. He has a good credit history with Fundación León 2000. He has used his past loans to buy materials, and he will use this loan to buy aluminum, iron and bronze. Don Leunel says that he has a lot of competition from other businesses like his that have a greater capacity.

Don Leunel has five children between the ages of 35 and 21. They are all married and have jobs. He says that he dreams of being able to travel to visit his older children who live outside of the country.

loans.use: To buy aluminum, iron and bronze

loans.name: Cruz

texts.es:
La Señora Cruz Hernández  tiene 48 años, ella vive en Santiago Sacatepequez tiene 7 hijos, es una mujer emprendedora que se dedica a la agricultura. Inició sembrando espinaca, tiempo después hizo planes para sembrar arveja.

Esto le ayudó bastante e hizo crecer su cosecha, actualmente cuenta con una manzana de terreno que utiliza para la siembra y cosecha de la arveja. Ella solicita su crédito ya  que necesita capital para comprar las compras necesarias para sacar adelante la cosecha,  como abono, herbecidas, caña de bambú, pita.   Su experiencia en este tipo de inversión le ayuda ya que su producto lo entrega a una cooperativa agrícola llamada cuatro pinos.  Ella desea a salir adelante con los planes que tiene y  seguir mejorando en la calidad de vida para ella y su familia.
texts.en:
Cruz Hernández, 48, lives in Santiago Sacatepequez; she has 7 children. She is an enterprising woman who is a farmer. She began growing spinach but later on began to make plans to plant peas. This was a great help to her and her crops increased. Currently she has a "manzana" (1.7 acres) of land on which she grows peas. She needs financing to buy the items needed to successfully bring her crops to harvest: natural fertilizer, herbicides, bambu stalks, pita (a kind of rope or cord made from agave). This kind of investment helps her because she turns over her crops to an agricultural cooperative called "cuatro pinos." She hopes to get ahead with her plans and to continue to improve her own and her family's quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy natural fertilizer, herbicides, and bamboo stalks.

loans.name: Gonzalo Mercedes

texts.en:
Gonzalo is 51 years old. He is married and his three children are in school: two are in high school and the oldest is in the last year of University.

28 years ago, Gonzalo learned how to weld from a family member and began to work with them. Little by little he saved up and started buying tools. Eventually he was able to open his own shop. Gonzalo has received three loans with Fundación León 2000 that he has used to buy tools for his workshop. Gonzalo is going to use this loan to buy materials like iron and welding rods. His goal is to expand his workshop and buy another piece of land so that he can have a separate space for his business and his home. Gonzalo reports that he has a conflict with the electric company that he has been dealing with.

loans.use: To buy materials like iron and welding rods

loans.name: Ines

texts.es: La Sra. Ines tiene una actividad de comercio de calzados en provincias y pueblos de nuestra ciudad, ella vende mercaderia nueva y a medio uso generalmente ella viaja pueblo a pueblo y conoce los días de feria de cada pueblo y es conocida por las personas de los pueblos a los que tambien le lleva mercaderia por pedidos, anteriormente ya saco un crédito con este tipo de financiamiento del cual está muy alegre ya que le ayudo a incrementar su capital, ella espera que con este crédito pueda cubrir las demandas de sus clientes para estas fiestas de fin de año ya que ofrecera productos nuevos para regalos.
texts.en:
Ines has a shoe business in the provinces and villages of our city. She generally sells new and lightly used goods. She travels from village to village and knows the market days of each town and is know by the people of the villages to whom she brings goods to order. She has previously had another loan of this type, and she is very happy because it helped her to increase her business capital. She hopes that, with this loan, she will be able to meet her customers' orders for the holidays and that she will offer new products for gifts.

Translated from Spanish by Alison Hynd, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase her stocks

loans.name: Josiane

texts.fr: K. Josiane est née le 26 Avril 1976 à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Mariée à DEDEGBE Eric, un enseignant, Josiane est mère de deux enfants, tous scolarisés. Josiane a un autre enfant à charge, en plus de ses deux enfants. La famille réside à Hèvié à Abomey Calavi (non loin de Cotonou, la capitale économique du Bénin). C’est depuis 4 ans que Josiane vit dans ce quartier. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Josiane a fréquenté l’école jusqu’à l’université. Mais depuis près de 4 ans, Josiane gère un télécentre où elle fait la photocopie et vend également des glaces. Josiane sollicite ce premier crédit auprès de ALIDé, afin de s’approvisionner en photocopieur, pour mieux satisfaire sa clientèle. Josiane ambitionne ouvrir plus tard un cyber centre dans la ville de Cotonou.
texts.en:
Josiane K. was born on 26 April 1976 in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin. She is married to Eric DEDEGBE, a teacher, and is the mother of two children, both of whom are in school. Josiane also takes care of one other child. The family has been living in Hèvié in Aborney Calavi (not very far from Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin) for the last four years. The couple provide together for the family. Josiane attended school all the way to university level. For the last four years, she has been the manager of a center where people have access to telephones and internet. She also provides photocopies as well as selling ice cream. She is asking for this first loan from Alidé in order to purchase a photocopier, in order to better serve her clients. Josiane hopes to one day open a cyber center in Cotonou.

Translated from French by Chloe Tuot, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase a photocopier

loans.name: Olfa Marlene

texts.es:
El banco comunal Mujeres Floreciendo está conformado por mujeres que luchan día a día demostrando que pueden ser más valiosas de lo que muchas personas creen y están dispuestas a salir adelante con sus familias. Este banco se inició en Cuenca,  ciudad hermosa llena de tradiciones y leyendas, dueña de una  belleza natural incomparable.
 
La señora Olfa  C. es socia activa  del banco comunal Mujeres Floreciendo, vive en uno de los sectores más hermosos de la ciudad de Cuenca como es Totoracocha, ella tiene 49 años de edad, está separada de su esposo hace 16 años desde que el migro al exterior y nunca más volvió  olvidándose de su familia y además no pago la deuda que adquirió para el viaje, forzándole a vender todo lo que tenía como son terrenos y su casa en Gualaceo, por lo que ahora vive arrendando, fruto de su matrimonio procreó  siete  hijos todos mayores de edad, de los cuales cuatro  son casados y tres  solteros pero viven independientes ya que ella tienen un nuevo compromiso del cual concibió una niña que ahora tiene nueve años, pero sin olvidarse de su madre por lo que le apoyan económicamente aunque sea un poco.

Olfa inició con su negocio de venta de  almuerzos  hace 6 meses, nos comenta que le va bien por lo que está obteniendo clientela pero le hacen falta algunas cosas como ollas, sartenes, cucharones y mas menaje de cocina, sus laboras inician a  las 9 de la mañana hasta las  2 de la tarde, el resto del día lava ropa ajena para aportar económicamente en su hogar.

Nuestra socia lleva cuatro años trabajando con los créditos de la Fundación siempre para salir invertir en su hogar,  con el nuevo préstamo va a comprar ollas, sartenes, cucharones, manteles, y todo lo que necesita para incrementar y su negocio y dar un mejor servicio a sus clientes

Su sueño es tener una casa propia.
texts.en:
The "Mujeres Floreciendo" communal bank is made up of women who daily struggle to show that they are more valuable than what many people think and that they are willing to do whatever is necessary to see their families progress. This bank was started in Cuenca, a beautiful city that is rich in tradition and legend, with an incomparable natural beauty. Olfa C. is an active member of the bank. She lives in one the the most beautiful neighborhoods of Cuenca, Totoracocha. She is 49 years old, separated from her husband for 16 years now, since he emigrated and was never heard from again. He also didn't repay the debt he incurred for travel expenses forcing her to sell all she owned, including her lands and her house in Gualaceo; she's currently a renter. The marriage produced 7 children, all of whom are now adults. Four of them are married and three are single, but live independently, because she's now in a new relationship ,the fruit of which is a 9-year-old daughter. However, they haven't forgotten their mother and they help her out economically with what little they can afford. Olfa started her lunch business 6 months ago. She tells us that she is doing well and acquiring regular customers. However, she still needs certain items like pots, pans, ladles, and more kitchen utensils. Her work day begins at 9am and goes until 2pm. The rest of the day she takes in laundry to earn additional income for household expenses. She has been working with the Foundation's credits for 4 years now, using them always to invest in her home. The new financing will be used to buy pots, pans, ladles, tablecloths, etc. and whatever else she needs to equip her business so that it will grow and she can provide better customer service. Her dream is to have her own house.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy pots, pans, cutlery, tablecloths, ladles, etc.

loans.name: Claudia

texts.es:
La señora Claudia es socia del Banco Comunal “Lupakas” desD. hace 3 meses, vive en el distrito D. Pilcuyo, provincia D. El Collao, departamento D. Puno. Ella tiene 54 años D. edad, es casada y tiene 5 hijos, D. los cuales 2 viven con ella. Claudia no estudió, ella se dedica a la compra y venta D. ropa.
Nos cuenta que con el primer préstamo solicitado al Movimiento Manuela Ramos que fue D. S/. 300.00 nuevos soles lo utilizó para aumentar su capital.
Ahora requiere un crédito D. S/. 500.00 nuevos soles con el que podrá comprar ropa.
Su sueño para el futuro es que su negocio crezca y pueda vivir tranquila y sin preocupaciones.
Lo que más le gusta D. su Banco Comunal son los ahorros y las reuniones con las socias.
texts.en:
Mrs. Claudia has been a member of the “Lupakas” Communal Bank for 3 months. She lives in the Pilcuyo district, El Collao Province, Department of Puno. She is 54 years old, married, and has 5 children, 2 of whom still live with her. Claudia never studied. She dedicates herself to buying and selling clothes. She tells us that the first loan she solicited from the Manuela Ramos Movement, for 300 New Sols, was used to augment her capital.

Now she needs a loan of 500 New Sols with which she will buy clothes to sell. Her dream for the future is that her business will grow and she can live tranquilly and without preoccupations. What she likes most about her Communal Bank are the savings and the reunions with fellow members.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: TO BUY CLOTHES TO SELL

loans.name: Maria Isabel

texts.es:
La señora MARIA ISABEL tiene 47 años, vive en el distrito D. LAREDO, provincia D. Trujillo, departamento La Libertad – Perú. Pertenece al Banco Comunal LAREDO. La socia presenta estudios hasta 6to D. primaria , es conviviente  y tiene 3 hijos D. los cuales 2 dependen económicamente D. ella. La socia se dedica a la  venta D. cosméticos. Con su primer crédito D. 300.00 nuevos soles pudo comprar cosméticos como: cremas, labiales, colonias, perfumes, shampoo, delineadores, etc. 
Con este crédito D. 2,500.00 nuevos soles comprará más cosméticos como: labiales, talcos, gel, cremas, polvos, colonias, perfumes, etc . Ella sueña con tener su restaurante y así poder generar mayores ganancias.
texts.en:
Maria Isabel is 47 and lives in the Laredo District, Trujillo Province, Department of Libertad, Perú. She is a member of the Laredo Village Bank, and is educated through the sixth year of primary school. She has a common law husband and three children, two of whom are dependent on her. She earns her living selling cosmetics. With her first loan, for 300 soles, she was able to buy cosmetics, including creams, lipsticks, colognes, perfumes, shampoo, eyeliners, etc. She plans to use this loan for 2,500 soles, to buy more cosmetics, like lipsticks, talcum powder, hair gels, creams, powders, colognes, perfumes, etc. Maria Isabel dreams of having her own restaurant so she can generate greater profits.

Translated from Spanish by Jill Heske, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy lipsticks, talcum powder, hair gels, creams, powders, colognes, perfumes, etc.

loans.name: Noellie

texts.fr: M. Noellie est née le 25 Décembre 1980 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à KPANGON, un géomètre, Noellie est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés. Noellie a deux autres enfants à charge. Noellie vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari à Hêvié à Abomey Calavi (non loin de Cotonou). Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Noellie a arrêté l’école au cours secondaire. Pour faire face à ses besoins et à ceux de ses enfants, Noellie vend des poissons congelés à son domicile. Noellie vend également du charbon de bois et de la tomate fraîche. C’est depuis 10 ans que Noellie exerce cette activité. Noellie s’approvisionne dans les poissonneries et à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C’est la première fois que Noellie sollicite un crédit auprès de ALIDé. Ce crédit lui servira à élever le niveau de son activité. Noellie ambitionne plus tard ouvrir une poissonnerie.
texts.en:
Noellie M. was born on 25 December 1980 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She is married to KPANGON, a land/building surveyor, and is the mother of three children, all of whom attend school. She also takes care of two other children. The family lives in Hêvié at Aborney Calavi (not very far from Cotonou). The couple both contribute to financially support the family. Noellie attended school until secondary school. In order to meet her needs and those of her children, she sells frozen fish from her home, as well as wood coal and fresh tomatoes. She has been doing this for 10 years. She stocks up from various fish shops (fishmonger's shops) and at Dantokpa, the international market in Benin. This is the first loan she has requested from Alidé. The loan will enable her to increase the level of activity of her business. She hopes one day to open a fish shop (fishmonger's shop).

Translated from French by Chloe Tuot, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase boxes and fish

loans.name: Maria Beatriz

texts.es:
El banco comunal Mujeres de Éxito  está integrado por un grupo de mujeres  dispuestas a demostrar que pueden salir adelante y superar los retos que la vida les pone en el camino, viven en diferentes localidades  de la ciudad de Cuenca, siendo esta ciudad reconocida por la UNESCO como  Patrimonio Cultural de la Humanidad por lo que es muy visitada por turistas nacionales y extranjeros atraídos por  la arquitectura de su centro histórico mezcla de lo medieval y moderno, así como por  sus tradiciones y la amabilidad de su gente.

La señora María C. es socia  fundadora  del banco comunal Mujeres de Éxito,  ella vive en la comunidad San Miguel en la parroquia El Valle, tiene 49 de edad se encuentra casada  y es madre de 10 hijos que ahora a tienen 32, 29, 26, 23, 20, 18, 16, 12, 9 y 7 años de edad,  sus dos primeros hijos ya son  casados y viven independientes,  los otros dos migraron al exterior, el de 20 años estudia y trabaja aportando  un poco económicamente con los gastos del hogar, el de  18 años trabaja como chofer, mientras que sus últimos hijos  estudian en el colegio CEDEC y en la escuela de la parroquia. Su esposo trabaja como relojero y también realiza fletes en su vehìculo, nos comenta que a  base de mucho esfuerzo y dejando de lado otros sueños lograron construir el  más grande sueño que es edificar su casa propia.

 María se dedica a la venta de queso en la Feria Libre (mercado de Cuenca) los días miércoles, viernes y sábados siendo su horario de 7 a.m. hasta las 2 p.m., los demás días de la semana se dedica a su familia y los quehaceres del hogar.

  Nuestra socia trabaja con los prestamos de la fundación hace seis años y medio, nos comenta que los prestamos le han beneficiado para seguir creciendo en su negocio y salir adelante y lo que más le gusta de su banco comunal es el apoyo que se brindan entre compañeras, así como la capacitación   que la Fundación imparte  ya que  les enseña a  ser personas productivas montando sus propios negocios así como el sistema de ahorro.  Con el nuevo préstamo realizado a la institución  va a invertir en la compra de queso ya que este producto se encuentra caro por la sequia que atraviesa la región,  su mayor sueño es  no tener más deudas.
texts.en:
The Communal Bank Mujeres de Exito [Women of Success] is made up by a group of women that are eager to get ahead in life and surmount any challenges in their way. They live in different areas in the City of Cuenca; the City of Cuenca is recognized by UNESCO as a World Heritage Site, and as a consequence is very visited by domestic and international tourists that are attracted to the architecture of its historic center that blends the medieval and modern, and by its traditions and kind people.

Maria C. is the founding member of the Communal Bank Mujeres de Exito. She lives in the San Miguel community in the El Valle Parish. Maria is 49 years old, married, and has 10 children that are now 32, 29, 26, 23, 20, 18, 16, 12, 9, and 7 years old. Her two oldest children are married and live on their own, the next two have migrated abroad, the 20 year old is studying and works to contribute a little financially to household expenses, the 18 year old works as a chauffeur, and her youngest children are studying at Colegio CEDEC and the Parish’s public school. Her husband works as a clockmaker and also uses his vehicle to provide transportation services. She tells us that with a great deal of work, and having put aside other dreams, they have been able to build their biggest dream which was to build their own house.

Maria sells cheese at the Feria Libre (the Market in Cuenca) on Wednesdays, Fridays, and Saturdays from 7am until 2pm; on other week days she dedicates herself to her family and household chores.

Our member has worked with loans from our foundation for the past six and a half years and she tells us that the loans have helped her to continue expanding her business and have also allowed her to get ahead in life. What she most enjoys about her Communal Bank is the support that they offer each other, and also the training that The Foundation provides; The Foundation teaches people how to start their own productive businesses and how to save. With the loan that she requested through the institution she will invest in the purchase of cheese given that this product has become expensive because of the drought that has hit through the region. Her biggest dream is to not have any more debts.

Translated from Spanish by Mariela Cedeno, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase cheese.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.es: La señora ELIZABETH tiene 33 años, vive en el distrito deL PORVENIR, provincia de Trujillo, departamento La Libertad – Perú. Pertenece al Banco Comunal CARIDAD II. La socia presenta estudios  hasta 5to de secundaria, es conviviente y tiene 2 hijos quienes dependen económicamente de ella. La socia se dedica a la venta de cosméticos como: labiales, cremas, perfumes, colonias, desodorantes, talcos y joyas. Este es su primer préstamo de 300.00 nuevos soles, el cual piensa invertir en la compra de otros cosméticos como: cremas, rubores, deliniadores, desodorantes, talcos, cremas, colonias, perfumes, etc. para tener en stock y aumentar sus ventas. Ella sueña con alquilar un puesto en el mercado en donde pueda vender sus cosméticos con mayor frecuencia y facilidad.
texts.en:
ELIZABETH, 33, lives in the PORVENIR district of Trujillo, La Libertad department, Perú. She is a member of the CARIDAD II communal bank. She finished 11th grade, lives with her life partner, and has two dependent children. She sells cosmetics like: lipsticks, creams, perfumes, colognes, deodorants, talcs and jewelry. This is her first, 300 new sol, loan which she plans to use to buy more cosmetics like those listed above in order to have sufficient stock to increase sales. She dreams with having a stall in the market where she can sell her cosmetics more often and more easily.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy creams, blushes, eyeliners, deodorants, talcs, colognes, perfumes, etc.

loans.name: Jeanne

texts.fr: S. Jeanne est née le 30 Décembre 1974 à Dogbo au Bénin. Mariée à EHOUN Théodore, un mécanicien auto, Jeanne est mère de quatre enfants, tous scolarisés. La famille vit ensemble à Hêvié à Abomey Calavi (non loin de Cotonou, la capitale économique du Bénin) depuis près de neuf ans. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. Jeanne n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Pour assurer ses besoins et ceux de ses enfants, Jeanne mène comme activité, la vente de maïs, de haricot et de farine de manioc à son domicile. C’est à Adja au Mono et à Parakou, dans le Nord du Bénin, que Jeanne s’approvisionne. Jeanne mène cette activité depuis 10 ans. Jeanne a obtenu une fois de crédit à ALIDé, crédit qu’elle a bien remboursé. Jeanne sollicite un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé en vue d’augmenter le stock de ses produits et de mieux satisfaire ses clients.
texts.en:
Jeanne S. was born on 30 December 1974 in Dogbo in Benin. Married to Théodore EHOUN, an auto mechanic, Jeanne is the mother of four children, all of whom attend school. The family has been living in Hêvié at Abomey Calavi (not very far from Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin) for the last nine years. The couple both contribute to financially support the family. Jeanne never attended school. In order to meet the needs of her children, she sells corn, beens and manioc flour from her home. She stocks up in Adja at Mono et a Parakou, in the north of Benin. She has been doing this for ten years. She obtained a previous loan from Alidé which was reimbursed. She is asking for a second loan in order to increase the stocks of products and better satisfy her clients.

Translated from French by Chloe Tuot, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase six bags of corn and four bags of beans

loans.name: Try Us Group

texts.en:
Here are members of the 'Try Us' group from the town of Magburaka in northern Sierra Leone. They are small-scale entrepreneurs who want a loan of SLL 500,000 each to enable them to expand their businesses.

Suliaman K. on the left in the photo is the leader of this group. The 52-year-old was born in Magburaka town and is married to a businesswoman; they have eight children between the ages of three and twenty-seven.

Sulaiman sells rice and palm oil (the favorite cooking oil in this country). He has been in this business for a very long time. With his share of the loan, he will buy gallons of palm oil and bags of rice, as much as the loan will permit.

loans.use: Buy gallons of palm oil and bags of rice

loans.name: Maria Esther

texts.es:
El banco comunal Mujeres de Éxito  está integrado por un grupo de dispuestas a demostrar que pueden salir adelante y superar los retos que la vida les pone en el camino, viven en diferentes localidades  de la ciudad de Cuenca, siendo esta ciudad reconocida por la UNESCO como  Patrimonio Cultural de la Humanidad por lo que es muy visitada por turistas nacionales y extranjeros atraídos por  la arquitectura de su centro histórico mezcla de lo medieval y moderno, así como por  sus tradiciones y su gente siempre  cálida. 

María Vélez es socia activa del banco Comunal  Mujeres de Éxito hace tres años y medio, tiene 31 años y  vive con su esposo que es ayudante en una carpintería del sector y con sus dos hijos de 8 6 años respectivamente, ellos estudian en la escuela Carlos Crespi,  aun no tienen  casa propia por lo que viven arrendando.

Durante  todo este tiempo como socia se ha beneficiado de los créditos de la institución invirtiendo  tanto en su casa como en su negocio de venta de ropa, esta actividad la realiza hace seis años en la feria libre del la ciudad, su horario de labores  es todos los miércoles de 7am a 6pm   el resto de la semana se dedica al cuidado de sus niños y los quehaceres domésticos.

Con el préstamo solicitado a la Fundación va a comprar mercadería como pantalones, sacos, blusas, camisas y más para mantener un buen surtido para la época navideña.

Su meta es llegar a tener una casa propia.
texts.en:
The "Mujeres de Éxito" communal bank is made up of a group determined to show that they can get ahead in life and overcome all obstacles that life puts in their path. They live in various neighborhoods of the city of Cuenca. Cuenca is recognized by UNESCO as a World Cultural Heritage Site, which makes it a highly attractive destination for both local and international tourists, who come to admire the architecture in the city center, which is a mixture of the medieval and the modern, and who come for its traditions and because of its welcoming residents. María Vélez, 31, has been an active member of the bank for the last three-and-a-half years. She lives with her husband, who is a carpenter's assistant, and their two children, 8 and 6 years old, respectively, who are students at Carlos Crespi school. They still don't own their own house; they are renters. During her time as a member she has benefitted from loans from the Institution that she has used both in home improvements and in her clothing sales business. She has been in this line of work for 6 years and is located in the city's free market. She works every Wednesday from 7am to 6pm. The rest of the week she cares for her children and sees to her domestic chores. With the financing requested now, she will buy merchandise like pants, coats, blouses, shirts, etc. so as to have a good and varied stock available for the Christmas season. Her goal is to own her own house someday.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy pants, blouses, shirts, coats, etc.

loans.name: Laurianne Inès

texts.fr: L. Laurianne Inès est née le 22 Juin 1985 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à HOUETO Mathieu, un employé au Port du Bénin, Laurianne Inès est mère de deux enfants, tous scolarisés. Il y a deux ans environs que la famille vit à Cococodji à Abomey Calavi (non loin de Cotonou). Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. Laurianne Inès a été à l’école jusqu’au cours secondaire. Depuis environs 7 ans, Laurianne Inès s’est mise à vendre des tissus et des sacs, par le système de distribution. Laurianne Inès mène comme activité secondaire, la vente de glacières. C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Laurianne Inès s’approvisionne. Laurianne Inès a obtenu une fois de crédit à ALIDé, crédit qu’elle a bien remboursé. C’est pour renforcer son activité et mieux satisfaire la demande de ses clients, que Laurianne Inès sollicite un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Laurianne Inès L. was born on 22 Juin 1985 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She is married to Mathieu HOUETO, an employer at the Port of Benin, and is the mother of two children, both of whom attend school. The family has been living in Cococodji at Aborney Calavi (near Cotonou) for approximately two years. The couple both contribute financially to support the family. Laurianne Inès attended school until secondary school. For the last seven years, she has been selling cloth/fabric and bags, via a business system comprised of purchasing, receiving, storing and distributing. As her second commercial activity, she sells ice boxes. It is in Dantokpa, the international market in Benin, that Laurianne Inès stocks up on supplies. She previous had one loan from Alidé which she reimbursed. It is in order to expand her business and better satisfy the demands of her clients that Laurianne Inès is asking for this second credit from Alidé.

Translated from French by Chloe Tuot, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase four large pieces of cloth and 15 bags for women

loans.name: María Esperanza

texts.es: Maria Esperanza es una muy buena cliente de Fundación León 2000 por lo que no es el primer financiamiento que solicita, pues ella sabe que este el único medio que ella posee para sacar adelante su negocio. Su actividad económica es la venta de mercadería en general, por lo que hace mas de las compras de sus productos las realiza en Managua porque es aquí donde le resulta mucho más favorable al por mayor, su negocio inicio aproximadamente hace unos 6 años con el apoyo de una tía e inicio con la venta de ropa interior y de niño. Actualmente ha incrementado su negocio, pero solicita este financiamiento para capital de trabajo pues se acerca la temporada navideña y es aquí donde obtiene más ganancias. Ella sueña con mejorar los ingresos de su familia.
texts.en:
Maria Esperanza is a very good client of the “Leon Foundation 2000.” This isn't the first loan she has requested. She believes that this is the only means of advancing her business.

Her economic activity is the sale of general merchandise and for that reason, she wishes to make most of her purchases in Managua, because that's where wholesale prices are more favorable. She started her business about 6 years ago with the help of an aunt, and began by selling underwear and children's clothing.

Presently, her business has grown, but she is soliciting financing for working capital. Christmas season is approaching and this is when she makes the most profit. She dreams of improving her family's income.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: TO BUY MORE INVENTORY FOR CHRISTMAS SALE

loans.name: Clément

texts.fr: T. Clément est né en 1966 à Dogbo au Bénin. Clément est marié à FANDJINOU Elise, une revendeuse. Clément a six enfants en charge, dont quatre sont ses propres enfants. Tous les enfants sont scolarisés. Il y a environs 8 ans que la famille vit à Akossavié à Abomey Calavi (non loin de Cotonou, la capitale économique du Bénin). Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Clément a fréquenté l’école jusqu’au cours secondaire, puis a appris le métier de cordonnier.  Clément mène cette activité depuis une quinzaine d’année à Akossavié. Clément s’approvisionne à Missèbo à Cotonou. C’est la première fois que Clément sollicite un crédit auprès de ALIDé, en vue de renforcer son activité et de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle. Clément ambitionne acquérir plus tard des machines plus performents pour son activité.
texts.en:
Clément T. was born in 1966 in Dogbo, in Benin. Clément is married to Elise FANDJINOU, who works in sales. He takes care of six children, four of whom are his own. All of them attend school. The family has been living in Akossavié at Aborney Calavi (near Cotnou, the economic capital of Benin) for approximately eight years. The couple both contribute financially to support the family. Clément went to school until secondary school, then learned how to be a cobbler. He has been a tailor for the past fifteen years in Akossavié, and stocks up on supplies in Missèbo in Cotonou. This is the first loan he has requested from Alidé, in order to expand his activity and better satisfy his customers. He hopes to acquire at a later date more powerful machines that are useful for his business.

Translated from French by Chloe Tuot, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase leather

loans.name: Rodine Group

texts.en:
These are members of the 'Rodine' group. They are small-scale businesspeople in the town of Magburaka in northern Sierra Leone. They have formed themselves into a group of four to apply for a loan from SMT/Kiva lenders. With a loan, they can expand their business, making more sales and better profit. Consequently, their living standard will improve.

The leader of this group is Ibrahim C. on the right in the photo. Ibrahim was born in Magburaka town about thirty-five years ago. He is married to a businesswoman and they have three children – two in secondary schools and one in primary school.

Ibrahim sells cosmetics, cigarettes, medicine, biscuits, mints, chewing gum, and many more items. He has been a businessman for approximately fifteen years now. With his share of the loan, he will buy cosmetics, cigarettes, biscuits, mints, chewing gum, and medicines.

loans.use: Buy cosmetics, cigarettes, biscuits, mints, chewing gum, and medicines

loans.name: Yelman

texts.es: Yelman V. tiene 28 años, este hombre muy trabajador su actividad económica es una pulpería hace mas de 7 años que se dedica a este negocio, por lo que la mayoría de sus clientes son vecinos y ciertas amistades. El inicio este negocio con mucho sacrificio propio pues tenía muchas ganas de salir delante y como todo padre y esposo responsable buscaba la manera de generar ingresos para su familia es así que él ha mantenido a su familia. El solicita este financiamiento con el fin de comprar productos para el hogar que son los que le solicitan. El desea tener una mejor estabilidad económica para el y su familia.
texts.en:
Yelman V., 28, is a very hard-working man. He has had a small grocery store for the last 7 years. Most of his customers are his neighbors and friends. He began the business with much sacrifice because he very much wanted to get ahead and, like any responsible father and husband, sought the way to earn income for his family. This is how he has supported his family. He asks for financing to buy products that his customers are requesting. He hopes to have better economic stability for himself and for his family.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital.

loans.name: Gbadessi

texts.fr: A. Gbadessi est née en 1959 au Bénin. Gbadessi vit depuis près de 10 ans à Cococodji, dans la commune d’Abomey Calavi au Bénin. Mariée à KPONOU Noel, un revendeur, Gbadessi est mère de deux enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Gbadessi vit seule avec ses enfants et supporte seule leurs charges. Gbadessi n’a pas été à l’école. Pour faire face à ses besoins, Gbadessi vend des tissus, de l’huile d’arachide et des savons, par le système de distribution. C’est depuis 20 ans que Gbadessi exerce cette activité. Gbadessi s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Gbadessi a obtenu une fois de crédit à ALIDé, et l’a bien remboursé. En vue d’élever le niveau de son activité, pour mieux répondre à la demande de la clientèle, Gbadessi sollicite un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
A. Gbadessi is born in 1959 in Benin. Gbadessi lives close to 10 years in Cococodji in the district of Abomey Calavi in Benin. Married to KPONOU Noel, a retailer, Gbadessi is the mother of two children, all in school. Gbadessi lives alone with her children and bears solely their expenses. Gbadessi has not been to school. In order to provide for her needs, she sells fabrics, peanut oil and soap through the distribution system. Gbadessi has been in this business for 20 years. She gets her supplies in Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. Gbadessi obtained a loan once from ALIDe and repaid it correctly. In view of raising the level of her business, in order to meet the resquests of her clientele, she is requesting a second loan from ALIDe.

Translated from French by Cletus Kuunifaa, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of 5 gallons of peanut oil and 5 pieces of fabric

loans.name: Giannina Mariela

texts.en:
Giannina is a client of Asociación Arariwa. She is member of a communal bank consisting of 22 members in Cusco. The group is called Fuente de Vida ("source of life" in Spanish).

Giannina is 26 years old, lives with her common-law husband, and is now pregnant with her first child. Giannina has been working with Arariwa for two years and her favorite aspect of Arariwa’s communal banking model is the savings component which is built into every loan--while making her monthly loan repayments, Giannina also pays an additional amount into her savings account. At the end of several loan cycles, these savings are returned to Giannina and the other communal bank clients, providing each of them with an additional source of capital to use to improve their business and quality of life.

Giannina’s business is buying and selling clothes, which she has been doing for the past 6 years. She buys her inventory in Lima, Arequipa and Cusco, and then sells the clothes in one of the main markets in Cusco. Giannina wants a loan to buy new lines of clothing to sell in her market stand and thereby grow her business.

Giannina appreciates Kiva lenders and thanks you for the loan. She promises to pay the monthly payments on time.

loans.use: Buy clothing to sell in market

loans.name: Ana

texts.es:
Ana, a sus 63 años es una mujer muy emprendedora y carismática, vive sola ya que es viuda y sus hijos son adultos e independientes. 
Durante la mañana se dedica a las labores de su hogar y el resto D. tiempo lo invierte en su trabajo, el cual es la venta de ropa a domicilio, actividad que realiza desde hace 5 años. Ana recibe pedidos de sus amigas, vecinas y familiares, gracias a los variados modelos y gran calidad de sus prendas son muy demandadas en su zona, dándole buenas ganancias. 

A ella le gusta mucho su trabajo, pues le permite sentirse independiente y útil, además las visitas que realiza a sus clientas no sólo es para la venta, sino también para conversar y aconsejarse mutuamente haciendo muy agradable su trabajo. 
Ana quiere mejorar en su negocio y es por ello que solicita la cantidad de mil soles para invertirla en más mercadería, como sábanas, edredones y cubrecamas.

Este es su quinto préstamo con MFP, ella es parte de un banco comunal llamado “Los amigos D. futuro” y se siente muy a gusto con su grupo. Asimismo, promete se puntual en el pago de sus cuotas.
texts.en:
Ana, at 63 years of age, is a very enterprising and charismatic woman. She lives alone because she is a widow and her children are all adults living independently. In the morning, she sees to her household chores. The rest of the time she works selling clothing door-to-door. She has been in this line of work for 5 years now. Ana gets orders from her friends, neighbors and relatives thanks to the variety of styles and good quality of the pieces she offers. Her wares are highly sought-after in her area and her sales produce good profits. She enjoyes her work very much because it allows her to feel useful and independent. Besides, the visits that she makes to her customers aren't just for the sales but also to chat and offer each other support and advice; this makes her work very pleasant. Ana wants to improve her business so she is asking for financing, 1000 soles, to buy more stock items like sheets, comforters and bedspreads. This is her 5th loan with MFP. She is a member of the "Los Amigos D. Futuro" communal bank and she is very pleased with her group. In addition, she pledges to repay her loan in a timely fashion.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy stock inventory.

loans.name: Ahignon

texts.fr: D. Ahignon est née en 1966 au Bénin. C’est une veuve qui n’a pas d’enfant. Ahignon vit seule depuis deux ans à Cocotomey, dans la commune d’Abomey Calavi au Bénin.
